(b)  It shall be unlawful or illegal and prohibited for a person or organization, either for profit or not for profit, to solicit monies, funds, or anything of value at street corners or street intersections in the city. However, a twice-per-year exception shall be granted for any organization whose members are trained in the areas of public health, safety, first aid and lifesaving techniques, and whose individual members meet a minimum age requirement of 18 years and who executes a hold harmless agreement in favor of the city. 
(Code 1960, § 25-5; Ord. No. 82-36, § 1, 4-27-1982; Ord. No. 82-161, § 1, 11-23-1982) 
Secs. 18-341-18-370. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VII. - PRECIOUS METAL DEALERS[7] 
Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
State Law reference- Secondhand dealers and secondary metals recyclers, F.S. ch. 538. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-371. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Precious metal means any item containing any gold, silver, or platinum, or any combination thereof. 
    Precious metal dealer means any person who normally or regularly engages in the business of buying used precious metal for resale and/or who possesses smelting equipment to melt down precious metals for resale, excluding the following: 
(1)  Any person, the principal business of whom is the retail sale of new goods and who accepts for trade-in previously owned precious metal in a transaction involving the sale of new goods, provided the traded-in precious metal was originally purchased from that person. 
(2)  Any person, the primary business of whom is dealing in coins, tokens, paper money, medals, and decorations. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-1; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(1), 8-22-1989) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-372. - Transaction forms and records. 
(a)  Every precious metal dealer shall prepare and submit a record approved as to type and form by the police chief. The record shall be clearly and legibly written in ink in the English language at the time of each acquisition and shall contain an accurate and true description of each article purchased, bartered, exchanged, or received. 
(b)  For precious metals the record shall include the following: 
(1)  A specific description of the precious metal item, including the type of item; the substance of which the item is made, whether gold, platinum or silver; the manufacturing company if that can be determined; and any permanent initialing or marking on the item, including a brand, monogram, or hallmark. 
(2)  The quantity of the precious metal purchased. 
(3)  The date of the purchase. 
(4)  The amount paid for the item. 
(c)  For precious metal dealers, records shall include the true name of the person dealt with, as well as such person's signature and right thumbprint, place of residence, sex, age, height, weight, build, color of hair, color of eyes, complexion and reasonable proof of identification by an exhibition of a driver's license or other picture identification or other reliable means of identification issued by a government agency; and final disposition of item, whether repurchased, sold, or disposed of. The record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon. For purposes of this article, credit cards, social security cards, handwritten identification cards, and nonphoto identification shall not constitute acceptable identification. A legible right thumbprint of the person from whom the article is acquired must be affixed to the approved transaction form. No entry made in such record shall be erased, obliterated, or defaced. 
(d)  Every precious metal dealer shall deliver to the office of the police chief or his designee the record within 72 hours of the date of acquisition of items covered under this article. 
(e)  Every precious metal dealer shall keep the following information chronologically, at the time of acquisition, on the premises in a solid binder-type record book, in ink, for a period of one year: 
(1)  Transaction number; 
(2)  Date and time of the transaction; 
(3)  Name of the customer; 
(4)  Customer's date of birth; 
(5)  Customer's address; 
(6)  Type of photo identification used by the customer and the number thereon; 
(7)  Type or description of the item and a serial number if any; 
(8)  The amount of money transacted and whether pawned or sold; and 
(9)  Final disposition of the item. 
(f)  Failure to comply with the recordkeeping portions of this article shall be subject to warnings, only, for the first three offenses. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-2; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(2), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-373. - Holding period. 
(a)  Items containing gold, silver, platinum, or other precious metal and jewelry, diamonds, gems, and other precious stones shall be held by a precious metal dealer, on the premises, or the precious metal dealer shall be able to produce the item within 24 hours, not including weekends, for a period of 15 days prior to sale, exchange, or other disposition thereof. However, this subsection shall not be applicable when the person known by the precious metal dealer to be the true owner of any article desires to redeem, repurchase, or recover such article at any time within the required hold period. The precious metal dealer shall keep a record of the proof of ownership presented by the true owner. 
(b)  The lawful owner of stolen property in the possession of any precious metal dealer may recover such property by informing the police department of the location of such property and providing the department with proof of ownership and a timely police report of the theft made. 
(c)  If a police officer has probable cause to believe that an item acquired by a precious metal dealer in the course of his business is the subject of a criminal investigation, the police officer may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order which would prohibit the release of such property for a period of 60 days. Upon release of such property, the precious metal dealer shall keep a record of the disposition thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-3; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(3), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-374. - Inspection of premises and records. 
    Any law enforcement officer shall, upon authorization of the police chief or his designee, have the right to inspect during normal business hours for the purpose of locating stolen goods and inspecting inventory and the records required to be kept by this article. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-4; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(4), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-375. - Certain acts and practices prohibited. 
    Each of the following acts of either a precious metal dealer or any of such dealer's employees is declared to be unlawful and shall subject the person to the penalties prescribed: 
(1)  Knowingly purchasing or otherwise acquiring any article covered by this article from: 
a.  Any person under the influence of drugs or alcohol; 
b.  Any minor under the age of 18, unless the minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian; or 
c.  Any person using a name other than his own. 
(2)  Refusing, denying, or interfering with the lawful inspection by a police officer of the records and inventory required to be kept by this article. 
(3)  Disposing of any property covered by this article contrary to this article. 
(4)  Pawning or loaning on any article covered by this article, between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m., the following morning. 
(5)  Carrying on the business of a precious metal dealer without a valid license or from any place other than the place designated in the license therefor. 
(6)  Failing or neglecting to comply with any applicable section of this article. 
(7)  Carrying on the business of a precious metal dealer utilizing a drive-through window for transactions. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-5; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(5), 8-22-1989) 
Secs. 18-376-18-400. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-401. - Information required. 
    Every applicant for a license to engage in the business of a precious metal dealer shall file with the licensing administrator a written application upon a form prepared and provided by the city, signed by the applicant. The fee for the license shall be $100.00, and the license shall be in effect for a period of one year unless otherwise revoked. This regulatory license is separate from and in addition to any occupational licenses required by the city. Every application for a license to engage in the business of a precious metal dealer shall be signed and acknowledged before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. Such application shall state the following: 
(1)  The names and residences of the applicant, if an individual, partnership or firm; or the names and dates of birth of the directors and officers and their residences, if the applicant is an association or corporation. 
(2)  The length of time such applicant, if an individual or partnership or the manager or person in charge if such applicant is an association or corporation, has resided at his current residence; his place of previous employment; whether he has been convicted of a felony and, if so, what offense, when, and in what court. 
(3)  Whether the applicant or manager of the applicant has or officers have been employed by a precious metal dealer. 
(4)  The detailed nature of the business to be conducted and the kind of materials to be collected, bought, sold, or otherwise handled. 
(5)  The premises where such business is to be located or carried on. 
(6)  The applicant accepts the license, if granted, upon the condition that it will be suspended by the police chief upon conviction of any offense enumerated in section 18-375. 
(7)  The applicant accepts the license, if granted, on the condition that he accepts the right of a city law enforcement officer to inspect his premises. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-6(a); Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-402. - Police background check. 
    Every applicant for a license required by this division and such applicant's employees shall be subject to a complete background investigation and shall be found to be suitable by the police chief to hold a license under this article. Each applicant/employee shall bear the costs of such background investigation. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-6(c); Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-403. - Issuance to persons convicted of certain offenses. 
(a)  No license as a precious metal dealer shall be granted to any person who shall have been convicted within ten years of the date of application of the offense of theft; larceny; embezzlement; conversion; obtaining money or property by false pretenses, fraud or deception; receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of altered property; burglary; or violation of F.S. § 812.051, unless the person has had his civil rights restored. If the licensee is a corporation or an association, the restrictions in this subsection apply to all officers and directors thereof. If the licensee is a partnership, the restrictions apply to each partner. 
(b)  No person licensed as a precious metal dealer shall employ any person in any precious metal dealer business who has within ten years of the date of employment been convicted of the offense of theft; larceny; embezzlement; conversion; obtaining money or property by false pretenses, fraud or deception; receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of altered property; burglary; or violation of F.S. § 812.051, unless the person has had his civil rights restored. The names and addresses of all part-time and full-time employees shall be submitted to the police chief within ten days of employment. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-7; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(7), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-404. - Numbering and contents. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall be numbered in the order in which they are issued and shall state clearly the location of the precious metal dealer's business, the date of issuance and expiration of the license, and the name and address of the licensee. Such license shall designate the place of business in or from which the precious metal dealer receiving the license shall be authorized to carry on such business. Such license is in addition to any other license required by applicable law. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-6(b); Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-405. - Revocation of license. 
    Any licensee who has been convicted of a violation of this article by a court of competent jurisdiction may have his license revoked or conditioned by the city council. For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall include any officers or directors of an association or corporate licensee and any partners of a partnership licensee. Upon such a conviction, the police chief may place on the city council agenda the matter of revoking or conditioning the license. Such agenda item shall be publicly advertised in a newspaper of local circulation, and written notice of the charges against the licensee shall be sent to him at least 14 days in advance, and the notice shall also contain the date, time, and place of hearing such agenda item. After consideration of the matter and allowing the licensee to be heard, the city council may revoke or condition the license. The factors to be considered by the police chief and the city council shall include the number and seriousness of the specific sections of this article which the licensee has been convicted of; the number and seriousness of prior convictions under this article; whether the penalty imposed pursuant to the convictions has been satisfied; and, based on such criteria, the danger to the health, safety, and welfare of the public of continued operation by the licensee. 
(Code 1960, § 22A-8; Ord. No. 89-79, § 2(8), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-406. - Limitation on number of licenses. 
    The number of licenses issued for precious metals dealers, as that term is defined in section 18-371, for operation in the city shall be determined based on the city's population. The total number of licenses issued for precious metals dealers shall be included in the number of secondhand goods dealers as that number is calculated pursuant to section 18-466(a). When additional licenses become available pursuant to section 18-466(b), the business tax administrator shall also accept entries from applicants interested in operating as precious metals dealers for inclusion in the drawing to be conducted pursuant to section 18-466(b) and if successful, inclusion in the eligibility list created as a result of the drawing for award of available licenses pursuant to section 18-466. Nothing in this section shall be construed to create a separate quota of licenses available exclusively for precious metals dealers based on the ratio established. 
(Ord. No. 2017-008, § 1, 2-28-2017) 
Secs. 18-407-18-430. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE VIII. - SECONDHAND GOODS DEALERS[8] 
Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
State Law reference- Secondhand dealers and secondary metals recyclers, F.S. ch. 538. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-431. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Secondhand dealer means any person engaged in the business of buying, selling, bartering, exchanging in any manner at retail or wholesale or otherwise dealing for profit in secondhand goods as defined in this section, whether or not at a fixed place of business. Such term includes pawnbrokers and all dealers who buy, trade, sell, or who make loans of money upon the deposit or pledge of any secondhand goods. However, nothing in this article shall apply to the following: 
(1)  Registered religious or charitable organizations selling reconditioned or used articles. 
(2)  Licensed garage sales. 
(3)  Any licensed and approved antique show/sale involving multiple dealers. 
(4)  Any licensed dealer whose primary business is used automobiles, trucks, boats, or other like items subject to state certificate of title laws wherein the item is registered, a certificate of title is issued to identify ownership or both. 
(5)  Any licensed and approved dealer/person buying and selling specific types or categories of tangible personal property, which is not identified as "secondhand goods," such as dealers in used car parts only, junk metal only, antique furniture only, artwork only, publications such as used books and magazines only, used construction equipment only. 
    Secondhand goods means personal property previously owned or used which is not purchased or sold as new and includes but is not limited to audio and video electronic equipment, including but not limited to television sets, radios, amplifiers, receivers, turntables, tape recorders, videotape recorders, speakers' and citizens' band radios; photographic equipment, including but not limited to cameras, lenses, electronic flashes, tripods and developing equipment; machinery; tools; electric motors; calculators; boat engines; boat outdrives; tires; hub caps; musical instruments; typewriters; computers; washers; dryers; kitchen appliances; and air conditioning units. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-1; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(1), 8-22-1989) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-432. - Transaction forms and records. 
(a)  Every secondhand dealer shall prepare and submit a record of transactions approved as to type and form by the police chief. The record shall be clearly and legibly written in ink in the English language at the time of each acquisition and shall contain an accurate and true description of each article purchased, bartered, exchanged, or received. 
(b)  For secondhand goods the record shall include a notation as to any identifying markings or characteristics, such as serial numbers; article brand name (i.e., Seiko, Minolta, RCA, IBM, etc.); model number; other identifying markings, such as owner-applied numbers; the amount of money or other consideration loaned thereon or paid or given therefor; the date and the time of the acquisition of such article by the secondhand dealer. 
(c)  The records of a secondhand dealer shall include the true name of the person dealt with, as well as such person's signature and right thumbprint, place of residence, sex, age, height, weight, build, color of hair, color of eyes, complexion and reasonable proof of identification by an exhibition of a driver's license or other picture identification or other reliable means of identification issued by a government agency, and final disposition of the item, whether repurchased, sold, or disposed of. The record shall contain the type of identification exhibited, the issuing agency, and the number thereon. For purposes of this article, credit cards, social security cards, handwritten identification cards, and nonphoto identification shall not constitute acceptable identification. A legible right thumbprint of the person from whom the article is acquired must be affixed to the approved transaction form. No entry made in such record shall be erased, obliterated, or defaced. 
(d)  Every secondhand dealer shall deliver to the office of the police chief or his designee the record within 72 hours of the date of acquisition of items covered under this article. 
(e)  Every secondhand dealer shall keep the following information chronologically, at the time of acquisition, on the premises in a solid binder-type record book, in ink, for a period of one year: 
(1)  Transaction number; 
(2)  Date and time of the transaction; 
(3)  Name of the customer; 
(4)  The customer's date of birth; 
(5)  The customer's address; 
(6)  The type of photo identification used by the customer and the number thereon; 
(7)  The type or description of the item and serial number if any; 
(8)  The amount of money transacted and whether pawned or sold; and 
(9)  The final disposition of the item. 
(f)  Failure to comply with the recordkeeping portions of this article shall subject the dealer to warnings, only, for the first three offenses. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-2; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(2), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-433. - Holding period. 
(a)  All secondhand property covered by this article acquired in the course of a secondhand dealer's business shall be held on the premises, or the secondhand dealer shall be able to produce the property within 24 hours, not including weekends, for a period of 30 days prior to disposition thereof. However, this subsection shall not be applicable when the person known by the secondhand dealer to be the true owner of any article desires to redeem, repurchase, or recover such article at any time within the required holding period. The secondhand dealer shall keep a record of the proof of ownership presented by the true owner. 
(b)  The lawful owner of stolen property in the possession of any secondhand dealer may recover such property by informing the police department of the location of such property and providing the department with proof of ownership and a timely police report of the theft made. 
(c)  If a police officer has probable cause to believe that an item acquired by a secondhand dealer in the course of his business is the subject of a criminal investigation, such police officer may apply to a court of competent jurisdiction for an order which would prohibit the release of such property for a period of 60 days. Upon release of such property, the secondhand dealer shall keep a record of the disposition thereof. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-3; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(3), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-434. - Inspection of premises and records. 
    Any law enforcement officer shall, upon authorization of the police chief or his designee, have the right to inspect during normal business hours for the purpose of locating stolen goods and inspecting inventory and the records required to be kept by this article. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-4; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(4), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-435. - Certain acts and practices prohibited. 
    Each of the following acts of either a secondhand dealer or any of his employees is declared to be unlawful and shall subject the person to the penalties prescribed: 
(1)  Knowingly purchasing or otherwise acquiring any article covered by this article from: 
a.  Any person under the influence of drugs or alcohol. 
b.  Any minor under the age of 18, unless the minor is accompanied by his parent or guardian. 
c.  Any person using a name other than his own. 
(2)  Refusing, denying, or interfering with the lawful inspection by a police officer of the records and inventory required to be kept by this article. 
(3)  Disposing of any property covered by this article contrary to this article. 
(4)  Pawning or loaning of any article covered by this article between the hours of 5:00 p.m. and 7:00 a.m. the following morning. 
(5)  Carrying on the business of a secondhand dealer without a valid license or from any place other than the place designated in the license therefor. 
(6)  Failing or neglecting to comply with any applicable section of this article. 
(7)  Purchasing or otherwise acquiring used motor vehicles or vessels unless registered and licensed by the state. 
(8)  Purchasing or otherwise acquiring firearms unless the dealer has met federal and state firearms licensing requirements. 
(9)  Carrying on the business of a secondhand dealer utilizing a drive-through window for transactions. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-5; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(5), 8-22-1989) 
Secs. 18-436-18-460. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-461. - Information required. 
    Every applicant for a license to engage in the business of a secondhand dealer shall file with the licensing administrator a written application, upon a form prepared and provided by the city, signed by the applicant. The fee for the license shall be $100.00, and the license shall be in effect for a period of one year unless otherwise revoked. This regulatory license is separate from and in addition to any occupational license required by the city. Every application for a license to engage in the business of a secondhand dealer shall be signed and acknowledged before a notary public or other officer authorized to administer oaths. Such application shall state the following: 
(1)  The names and residences of the applicant, if an individual, partnership or firm; or the names and dates of birth of the directors and officers and their residences, if the applicant is an association or corporation. 
(2)  The length of time such applicant, if an individual or partnership or the manager or person in charge, if such applicant is an association or corporation, has resided at his current residence; his place of previous employment; whether he has been convicted of a felony, and if so, what offense, when, and in what court. 
(3)  Whether the applicant or manager has or officers of the applicant have been employed by a secondhand dealer. 
(4)  The detailed nature of the business to be conducted and the kind of materials to be collected, bought, sold, or otherwise handled. 
(5)  The premises where such business is to be located or carried on. 
(6)  The applicant accepts the license, if granted, upon the condition that it will be suspended by the police chief upon conviction of any offense enumerated in section 18-435. 
(7)  The applicant accepts the license, if granted, on the condition that he accepts the right of a city law enforcement officer to inspect his premises. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-6(a); Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-462. - Police background check. 
    Every applicant for a license required by this division and his employees shall be subject to a complete background investigation and found to be suitable by the police chief to hold a license under this article. Each applicant and employee shall bear the costs of such background investigation. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-6(c); Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-463. - Issuance to persons convicted of certain offenses. 
(a)  No license as a secondhand dealer shall be granted to any person who shall have been convicted within ten years of the date of application of the offense of theft; larceny; embezzlement; conversion; obtaining money or property by false pretenses, fraud or deception; receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of altered property; burglary; or violation of F.S. § 812.051, unless the person has had his civil rights restored. If the licensee is a corporation or an association, the restrictions in this subsection apply to all officers and directors thereof. If the licensee is a partnership, the restrictions in this subsection apply to each partner. 
(b)  No person licensed as a secondhand dealer shall employ any person in any secondhand dealer business who has within ten years of the date of employment been convicted of the offense of theft; larceny; embezzlement; conversion; obtaining money or property by false pretenses, fraud or deception; receiving stolen property; dealing in stolen property; possession of altered property; burglary, or violation of F.S. § 812.051, unless the person has had his civil rights restored. The names and addresses of all part-time and full-time employees shall be submitted to the police chief within ten days of employment. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-7; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(7), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-464. - Numbering and contents. 
    All licenses issued under this division shall be numbered in the order in which they are issued and shall state clearly the location of the secondhand dealer's business, the date of issuance and expiration of the license, and the name and address of the licensee. Such license shall designate the place of business in or from which the secondhand dealer receiving the license shall be authorized to carry on such business. Such license is in addition to any other license required by applicable law. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-6(b); Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(6), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-465. - Revocation. 
    Any licensee who has been convicted of a violation of this article by a court of competent jurisdiction may have his license revoked or conditioned by the city council. For the purposes of this section, the term "licensee" shall include any officers or directors of any association or corporate licensee and any partners of a partnership licensee. Upon such a conviction, the police chief may place on the city council agenda the matter of revoking or conditioning the license. Such agenda item shall be publicly advertised in a newspaper of local circulation, and written notice of the charges against the licensee shall be sent to him at least 14 days in advance, and the notice shall also contain the date, time, and place of hearing such agenda item. After consideration of the matter and allowing the licensee to be heard, the city council may revoke or condition the license. The factors to be considered by the police chief and the city council shall include the number and seriousness of the specific sections of this article which the licensee has been convicted of; the number and seriousness or prior convictions under this article; whether the penalty imposed pursuant to the convictions has been satisfied, and based on such criteria, the danger to the health, safety, and welfare of the public of continued operation by the licensee. 
(Code 1960, § 24A-8; Ord. No. 89-78, § 2(8), 8-22-1989) 
Sec. 18-466. - Limitation on number of licenses. 
(a)  The number of licenses issued for secondhand goods dealers, as that term is defined in section 18-431, for operation in the city shall be limited to a number of establishments based on a ratio of one secondhand goods dealer for every four thousand five hundred (1:4,500) inhabitants of the city. For this purpose, the population of the city shall be that determined in the last preceding United States Census for the city. This limitation shall not apply to retail jewelry stores engaging in limited secondhand transactions pursuant to section 98-1111(21). 
(b)  When additional secondhand goods dealers licenses become available due to the growth in population or as a result of attrition in existing licenses, the local business tax administrator shall publish a notice of the time, date and place at which the local business tax administrator shall conduct a drawing for said licenses. The notice shall be published at least ten days in advance of the drawing. All interested applicants shall register for the drawing in a form and pursuant to the procedures adopted by the city. The business tax administrator shall create a list of interested applicants in the order in which their names are drawn to establish the priority in which the interested applicant's application shall be processed for approval and awarded a license. The business tax administrator shall not accept applications from interested applicants, as ranked, in excess of the available number of licenses available to be issued. 
(c)  The winner(s) of the drawing shall complete a business tax application form and return the completed form with all information required to the business tax division within 60 days of selection. The applicant must comply with all applicable code requirements to operate as secondhand goods dealer at the proposed location, including but not limited to, all applicable requirements under this article, chapter 86, and all other zoning, building and fire code requirements. If the application is denied, the business tax administrator can accept an application from the next interested applicant in the order of their ranking from the list created as a result of the drawing once all administrative appeals have been exhausted by the rejected applicant. If the list of interested applicants is exhausted, the business tax administrator must conduct another drawing in order to establish an eligibility list. 
(Ord. No. 2017-007, § 1, 2-28-2017) 
Secs. 18-467-18-490. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IX. - PRIVATE PROTECTION AGENCIES[9] 
Footnotes: 
--- (9) --- 
State Law reference- Private investigative, private security and repossession services, F.S. ch. 493. 

DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-491. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Private protective agency or patrol agency means any person who is engaged in the business of acting as private watchman over the property, real or personal, of persons within the city limits. 
(Code 1952, § 22.1; Code 1960, § 22-10) 
Cross reference- Definitions generally, § 1-2. 
Sec. 18-492. - Employment of minors. 
    No licensee under this article shall employ any person under the age of 21 years to act as watchman or patrolman. 
(Code 1952, § 22.7; Code 1960, § 22-14) 
Sec. 18-493. - Information about employees. 
    No licensee under this article shall employ any person without having furnished to the police chief the name, address and a brief history of such employee. 
(Code 1952, § 22.8; Code 1960, § 22-16) 
Secs. 18-494-18-520. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-521. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in the business of patrol agency or private protective agency without having first obtained a license from the city clerk and without complying with all of the sections of this article. 
(Code 1952, § 22.2; Code 1960, § 22-11) 
Sec. 18-522. - Application; investigation by police. 
(a)  Any person desiring to engage in the business of private protective agency or patrol agency shall first make application to the finance director for a license upon a form to be prescribed by the finance director, which form shall set out in detail the information sought therein. 
(b)  Upon receiving the application the city clerk shall instruct the police chief to make and the police chief shall make a proper investigation for the purpose of ascertaining whether the applicant is qualified to engage in the occupation of private protective agency or patrol agency, as well as the past record of such applicant on the question of honesty, integrity, truthfulness and other qualifications of like nature. 
(c)  If, after investigation, the police chief shall, in writing, state that he is of the opinion that the applicant is qualified and shall so notify the city clerk, the license shall be issued to the applicant upon the payment of the license tax required by section 86-45, payable on the same basis and for the same term as are other city licenses. 
(Code 1952, §§ 22.3-22.5; Code 1960, § 22-12) 
Sec. 18-523. - Bond required. 
    Before any licensee shall be authorized to undertake the business for which the license required by this division is issued, he shall first furnish a bond in the penal sum of $5,000.00, which bond shall be approved by the city attorney as to its form and sufficiency of its surety. The condition of such bond shall be that it shall run and be payable to the city and shall be conditioned generally as follows: 
"The condition of the above obligation is such that whereas, the said principal has been issued a license to operate and maintain a _______ in the City of Hialeah in accordance with the terms and provisions of section 86-45, and 
"NOW, THEREFORE, if the said principal shall well and truly comply with all of the terms and conditions of said section and shall well and truly indemnify any and all persons of and from any wrongful or negligent acts committed by the principal or any agents or employees of the principal, then this obligation to be in full force, null and void, otherwise to remain in effect. 
(Code 1952, § 22.6; Code 1960, § 22-13) 
Sec. 18-524. - Photographs and fingerprints required. 
    No person, whether the applicant himself, or if a corporation, no persons employed by such corporation, or if an individual, no persons employed by such individual shall perform any services whatsoever in connection with the occupation or business of private protective agency or patrol agency without first having given to the police chief one or more photographs of all persons engaged in such business or occupation or employed therein, together with the fingerprints of such persons, and not until after due investigation by the police chief finding such persons to be properly qualified as to honesty and integrity and past record. 
(Code 1952, § 22.9; Code 1960, § 22-15) 
Sec. 18-525. - Revocation. 
    Any license issued under this division shall be revocable at the will of the city council if after a hearing the council finds that the licensee and other persons employed by him have been guilty of wrongful acts. 
(Code 1952, § 22.10; Code 1960, § 22-17) 
Secs. 18-526-18-550. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE X. - RACE PREDICTION PUBLICATIONS 
DIVISION 1. - GENERALLY 

Sec. 18-551. - Contents of publications. 
    No sheet, paper or pamphlet described in section 18-581 shall be printed except under the true and correct name of the person making such prediction, and all such sheets, papers and pamphlets shall contain the following words stamped thereon: "Predictions made prior to 1:00 p.m. on the _____ day of ________, ___" with the true date inserted in the blank spaces appearing thereon. 
(Code 1952, § 23.5; Code 1960, § 22-7) 
Sec. 18-552. - Registration of predictions with police chief. 
    No person shall display, sell or offer for sale any sheet, paper or pamphlet described in section 18-581 without first having registered the prediction of the horses or dogs designated to win with the police chief or his duly authorized agent not later than 1:00 p.m. of the day on which the race is to be held and about which the prediction is made. 
(Code 1952, § 23.6; Code 1960, § 22-8) 
Sec. 18-553. - Predictions subsequent to race. 
    No person shall print or cause to be printed any sheet, paper or pamphlet predicting the outcome of any horse or dog race subsequent to the holding of such race. 
(Code 1952, § 23.7; Code 1960, § 22-9) 
Secs. 18-554-18-580. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - LICENSE 

Sec. 18-581. - Required. 
    No person shall engage in or manage the business of displaying, selling or offering for sale any sheet, paper or pamphlet, the purpose of which is to predict the outcome of any horse or dog race, without first having obtained a license therefor. 
(Code 1952, § 23.1; Code 1960, § 22-4) 
Sec. 18-582. - Registration; fingerprinting and photographing of applicant; effect of felony conviction. 
    Before any applicant for a license required under this division shall be authorized to engage in such business, he must first present himself to the police chief for fingerprinting and registering and shall obtain a certificate from the police chief certifying that the applicant has not been convicted of any felony prior to the date of the application. If the applicant for such license has been convicted of any felony prior to his application, no license shall be issued. No person shall engage in or be employed in managing, displaying, selling or offering for sale any sheet, paper, or pamphlet covered by this article without first having been registered and fingerprinted by the police chief and issued a certificate certifying that he has not been convicted of any felony. If such person shall have been convicted of a felony, it shall be unlawful for him to engage in or be employed in the business described in this article. 
(Code 1952, § 23.2; Code 1960, § 22-5) 
Sec. 18-583. - Issuance; tax. 
(a)  Upon presentation to the city clerk of a certificate from the police chief provided for in section 18-582 and upon filing an application with the city clerk and payment of the annual license tax provided in section 86-45 to the city clerk, the applicant shall be issued a license authorizing him to engage in such business. 
(b)  All applicants shall be required to pay the full annual tax regardless of the date of the issuance of the license. 
(Code 1952, § 23.3; Code 1960, § 22-6) 
Secs. 18-584-18-610. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE XI. - USED TIRE DEALERS 

Sec. 18-611. - Disposal of used tires. 
(a)  It shall be unlawful to dump or dispose of used tires on any property within the city. 
(b)  Disposal of used tires by any person shall be by resale, recycling, or disposal at an approved dumping facility or other legal method. 
(Code 1960, § 21-60; Ord. No. 88-49, §§ 1, 2, 4-26-1988) 
Sec. 18-612. - Registration of business. 
(a)  All businesses that accumulate used tires, including but not limited to tire dealers, service stations which perform tire services, garages which deal in tire services, tire disposal companies, and department stores with automotive centers, shall register with the licensing section. 
(b)  There shall be registration forms provided by the licensing section which shall include the following: 
(1)  The name and address of the business. 
(2)  The owner's name and address. 
(3)  The storage location of all used tires. 
(4)  The method of disposal of used tires. 
(5)  Execution by the owner, and all such registration forms shall be notarized. 
(c)  Quarterly (December 31, March 31, June 30 and September 30), each such registered business shall file a notarized report describing the number of tires disposed of during the quarter and the method of disposal used, the company used for disposal if other than the registered business, and the place of disposal. 
(d)  No registered business shall be permitted to give used tires to any customer for disposal by the customer. 
(e)  Failure of any registered business to comply with subsections (a) through (d) of this section may, in addition to other penalties, result in the revocation of the occupational license of the business. 
(f)  All registered businesses shall, upon request, provide books, records, receipts or other documentation to any duly authorized city inspector or police officer upon request during reasonable business hours, for the purpose of providing proof of compliance. 
(g)  Illegal or improper disposal of used tires by any registered business, firm, corporation, or person or the illegal or improper disposal of used tires by any registered business, firm, corporation or person, on behalf of the registered business, shall result in the revocation of the occupational license of the registered business, as well as other penalties provided in this Code. 
(h)  All businesses registered under this section shall be required to mark their used tires with a branding device that shows their city occupational license number. 
(Code 1960, § 21-61; Ord. No. 88-50, §§ 1-7, 4-26-1988; Ord. No. 93-25, § 1, 3-9-1993; Ord. No. 02-15, § 1, 3-26-2002) 
Chapter 22 - CODE ENFORCEMENT[1] 
Footnotes: 
--- (1) --- 
Cross reference- Administration, ch. 2; buildings and building regulations, ch. 14; minimum housing code, § 50-26 et seq.; land development code, pt. III. 

ARTICLE I. - IN GENERAL[2] 

Footnotes: 
--- (2) --- 
Editor's note- Ord. No. 2018-017, § 1, adopted February 27, 2018, amended article I in its entirety to read as herein set out. Former article I, § 22-1, pertained to additional remedies. See Cede Comparative Table for complete derivation. 

Sec. 22-1. - Purpose. 
    It is the intent of this chapter to promote, protect and improve the health, safety and welfare of the citizens of the city by the creation of code compliance procedures that will provide an equitable, expeditious, efficient and effective method for enforcement of the codes, ordinances, rules and regulations of the city, Miami Dade County, State of Florida, and any other statutes, codes, ordinances, rules and regulations that the city is authorized to enforce within its jurisdiction. Pursuant to F.S. § 162.03, as amended from time to time, the city hereby adopts an alternative code enforcement system for the enforcement of its own codes, ordinances, rules and regulations. Any civil penalty imposed or collected pursuant to this chapter shall not limit any other civil or administrative remedies that the city may be entitled to by law. 
(Ord. No. 2018-017, § 1, 2-27-2018) 
Sec. 22-2. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Administrative hearing shall mean a hearing before the special master to contest the findings of a code inspector that resulted in the issuance of a notice of civil violation; to determine whether and when the violator complied with the special master order; to determine whether the violator is entitled to a reduction of the fines accrued pursuant to an order; or for any other ancillary decision in the prosecution of an enforcement matter required to be made by a special master pursuant to this chapter. 
    Affidavit of non-compliance shall mean an affidavit of the code inspector certifying that the violator has failed to correct the violation within the time allowed for correction; failed to pay the civil penalty as set forth in the order of the special master; or otherwise failed to comply with a special master order. 
    Appeal shall mean a review by a court of competent jurisdiction of a final administrative order of the special master. 
    Code means any of the several chapters of the City of Hialeah Code of Ordinances, or any other code, ordinance or rule duly adopted by the city council, which codes may be cited either by the section number from the City of Hialeah Code of Ordinances, or by the section numbers in the Miami Dade County Code, building code, fire codes or other technical codes that city is authorized to enforce within its jurisdiction. 
    Code compliance official means the supervisor of the code compliance division of the city. 
    Code enforcement clerk means the administrative staff person or designee in the code compliance division responsible for the preparation, development and coordination of the administrative hearing and case management services necessary to support the special master. 
    Code inspector means the authorized agent or employee of the city whose duty it is to ensure compliance with the code. 
    Continuing violation means any violation that remains uncorrected beyond the reasonable time period established for correction contained in either the notice of civil violation or the final order of the special master, whichever is applicable. For each day of continued violation after the time period for correction has run, an additional penalty in the same amount as the original violation shall accrue. 
    Notice means the mailing of a notice of civil violation or notice of administrative hearing as required by this chapter to the person required to be notified of a code violation. 
    Person means any and all persons, natural or artificial, including any individual, firm, association, joint venture, partnership, or other entity, however organized. 
    Reasonable cause shall mean that a reasonable belief exists that a code provision has been violated and that the violator committed, or is the person responsible for the creation or maintenance of the violation. 
    Repeat violation is a recurring violation of an ordinance or law by a violator who has previously been found guilty of the same violation within the last five years, notwithstanding that the violations may have occurred at different locations. 
    Violator means the person who allegedly committed the violation of the code or is responsible for the violation of the code. 
    Uncorrectable or irreparable violation means a violation which cannot be remedied after the violation was committed because the violation constitutes a single prohibited act rather than an ongoing condition or circumstance. Each reoccurrence of an uncorrectable violation shall constitute a separate violation and shall subject the violator to an additional penalty. 
(Ord. No. 2018-017, § 1, 2-27-2018) 
Sec. 22-3. - Civil offenses and penalties. 
    The violation of any city ordinance or any lawful rule, regulation or written order of the city shall constitute a civil offense punishable by civil penalty in the amount provided for in this chapter as amended by the city council from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 2018-017, § 1, 2-27-2018) 
Sec. 22-4. - Additional remedies. 
    Any person who violates a section of this chapter or any lawful rule, regulation or written order promulgated under this chapter is subject to injunction or other equitable relief to enforce compliance with or prohibit the violation of this chapter. Further, such person is liable for any damage to the city caused by such violation and for the reasonable costs and expenses incurred by the city in enforcing this chapter, including, but not limited to the costs of enforcement inspections, reasonable repairs, preparation of enforcement reports, photographs, title searches, postage and other administrative costs for enforcement and collection, except as so limited in this chapter. All such sums shall become immediately due and payable upon order of the special master or court. 
(Ord. No. 2018-017, § 1, 2-27-2018) 
Secs. 22-5-22-30. - Reserved.
