    Nothing herein contained shall be constructed as prohibiting the further extension of water mains by the department and the defraying of all or any part of the cost thereof out of funds pursuant to authorized expenditures from city funds or bond proceeds. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-49. - Installation of mains both within and outside the city limits. 
    Provisions of this chapter apply to extensions of water mains both within and outside the territorial limits of the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-50. - Use of fire hydrants for other than firefighting purposes. 
    The operation of fire hydrants by other than authorized personnel is prohibited. The department may permit the use of water from a fire hydrant for construction or other purposes provided the customer shall properly apply for and receives a department issued hydrant meter, backflow prevention device and a hand-operated valve if required. Only city employees or other authorized representatives of the customer may operate the hydrant to provide water to the meter. The necessary fees for the installation of the hydrant meter must have been paid in advance. Water provided through the meter shall be paid at prevailing rates for water use. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-51. - Private fire protection systems generally. 
(a)  Fire protection systems may be installed on private property by the owner thereof at the property owner's own cost, provided the installation shall be done under the supervision and subject to the inspection of and according to the requirements of the building division. The maintenance of such systems shall be at the cost and expense of the property owner. Annual fees for such systems shall be paid, and, if not, the fire protection systems shall be disconnected from the waterworks system. 
(b)  No fixtures whatsoever, other than those used for extinguishing fires may be connected to the fire protection system. If the department has reason to believe that a fire protection system is being used for purposes other than fighting fires, the department shall require the owner of such system to pay to the department the cost of installing an approved water meter to monitor the use of water. Such water meter will be established as a regular account, subject to all rules, regulations and appropriate water rates of this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-52. - Connection of fire protection systems; systems with private fire hydrants. 
    Fire protection systems connected to water mains of the department shall contain an approved detector check valve to detect possible leakage or unauthorized use of water for other than fighting fires from the fire protection system. If the periodic reading by the city of the backflow preventer indicates that water is being used from the fire protection system for uses other than fighting fires or if the system shows excessive leakage, the property owner shall pay the department the cost of installing an approved water meter, and the meter shall be established as a regular account, subject to all rules, regulations and appropriate water rates of this chapter. All hydrants shall be painted colors specified by the department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-53. - Requirements for fire hydrants. 
    Before the department installs or authorizes the installation of any distribution mains or before any new commercial, industrial or residential service is connected to an existing water main, such facilities shall include the necessary number of fire hydrants and fire hydrant appurtenances of a size, type and spacing as specified by the department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-54. - Adoption of water use efficiency standards manual. 
    The city hereby adopts by reference the latest edition of the county water use efficiency standards manual, as amended from time to time. As of July 1, 2008, each applicant for water service to a new residential, commercial or industrial development shall comply with the water use efficiency standards approved by the county as provided in the water use efficiency standards manual. Each application shall identify and describe the water use efficiency standards incorporated in the new development. 
(Ord. No. 2008-26, § 1, 4-8-2008) 
Secs. 94-55-94-65. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE III. - SANITARY SEWERS 

Sec. 94-66. - Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Authorized representative of industrial user means: 
(1)  A principal executive officer of at least the level of vice president, if the industrial user is a corporation; 
(2)  A general partner or proprietor, if the industrial user is a partnership or proprietorship, respectively; or 
(3)  A duly authorized representative of the business entity, if such representative is responsible for the overall operation of the facilities from which the direct discharge originates. 
    Biochemical oxygen demand ("BOD") means the quantity of oxygen utilized in the biochemical oxidation of organic matter under standard laboratory procedures in five days at 20° Celsius expressed in milligrams per liter by weight. 
    Building sewer means the connecting pipe from a building, beginning feet outside the inner face of the building wall, to the connection with the service lateral, provided by the city, at the property line. 
    Building system means a functionally related group of elements, components and/or equipment, such as the electrical, plumbing and mechanical systems of a building. 
    Capital charge, wastewater means a nonrefundable capital expansion fee or impact charge designed to recover from future customers generating the demand for wastewater service. The amount of the capacity fee is based on the city's investment in the existing and estimated costs of treatment plants and specific backbone trunk and intercepting sewers to be utilized by future customers plus the related carrying costs incurred by the city while waiting for the future customer to connect to the system. 
    Certificate of occupancy ("CO") means an official document evidencing that a building satisfies the requirements of the city for the occupancy of a building. 
    Change of use means a change of use as determined by the planning division. 
    Clean Water Act means the Federal Water Pollution Control Act (PL 92-500), as amended. 
    Color means the true color of the light transmitted through the waste solution after removing suspended material, including the pseudocolloidal particles. 
    Commercial building means any building, structure or improvement other than single-family residence, townhouse or duplex. 
    Commitment means an official document authorizing performance of a specific activity regulated by this article. 
    Composite sample means a minimum of eight grab samples collected at equally spaced one-hour intervals, for each operating shift and proportioned according to flow. 
    Daily maximum means the results of a one-day sampling; either a single grab or composite sample during a 24-hour period. 
    Department means the department of water and sewers of the city that shall have jurisdiction and cognizance over the treatment and collection works of the city and all matters relating to the use, management, operation and maintenance thereof. 
    Director means the head of the department who shall be responsible for the management of the business of such department. 
    Domestic wastewater means all liquid and waterborne pollutants, exclusive of unpolluted water or wastewater or wastes from processes or operations in industrial establishments. 
    EPA means the United States Environmental Protection Agency. 
    40 CFR 403 means Part 403 of Title 40 of the Code of Federal Regulations entitled "General Pretreatment Regulations for Existing and New Sources of Pollution." 
    Grab sample means a single "dip and take" sample collected at a representative point in the discharge system. 
    Industrial user means any nongovernmental user of publicly owned treatment works defined by the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1987, of the United States Office of Management and Budget, as amended and supplemented under the following divisions: 
Division A, agriculture, forestry and fishing; 
Division B, mining; 
Division D, manufacturing; 
Division E, transportation, communication, electric, gas and sanitary services; 
Division I, services. 
    Industrial waste means the liquid and waterborne pollutants resulting from processes or operations employed in industrial establishments, as defined in the Standard Industrial Classification Manual, 1987, of the United States Office of Management and Budget of the federal government, as amended and supplemented, under the following divisions: 
Division A, agriculture, forestry and fishing; 
Division B, mining; 
Division D, manufacturing; 
Division E, transportation, communication, electric, gas and sanitary services; 
Division I, services. 
    Monthly average means the average results of all sampling, either grab samples or 24-hour composite samples taken during a calendar month. 
    Normal strength means a wastewater strength determined by the department to be typical for domestic users. 
    NPDES permit means national pollutant discharge elimination system permit that is issued pursuant to section 402 of the Clean Water Act. 
    pH means the logarithm (base 10) of the reciprocal of the concentration of hydrogen ions in moles per liter of solution. Stabilized pH is that result after a sample of the waste has been subjected to natural aeration. 
    Physical value means the country property appraiser's assessed value or certified appraised by a person licensed and qualified to provide appraisals for the state. 
    Point-of-connection means the location where a building sewer or other privately owned and maintained sanitary sewer or system that is connected with or shall be connected to the treatment works of the city. 
    Pretreatment standard means a national categorical pretreatment standard. Any regulation containing pollutant discharge limits promulgated by the EPA according to sections 307(b) and (c) of the Clean Water Act that applies to a specific category of industrial users. 
    Private wastewater disposal system means any facilities for wastewater treatment and disposal not maintained and operated by the department. 
    Properly shredded garbage means the organic wastes resulting from the preparation, cooking and dispensing of foods that have been shredded to such degree that all particles will be carried freely under the flow conditions normally prevailing in public sewers, with no particle being greater than one-half inch in any dimension. 
    Remodeling means work that changes the original size, location or material of the components of a building. 
    Residential building means any single-family, duplex, townhouse. 
    Sanitary sewer means a public sewer owned or operated by the city that carries liquid and waterborne wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industrial plants and institutions, together with minor quantities of ground and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Service area means the area within which the department provides complete wastewater collection and disposal service, comprising the city and areas served outside the city territorial limits. Nothing herein shall be constructed as obligating the city or the department to furnish or extend wastewater collection service to unsewered areas within the service area. The provision of service shall be left to the discretion of the department and will be further subject to the application for service process as provided herein. 
    Service lateral means the connecting pipe extending from the sanitary sewer to the connection with a building sewer at the property line. 
    Sewer improvement service charge means a nonrefundable fee from customers receiving benefit, which recovers the cost of providing the local or neighborhood collection system. 
    Sewer improvements mean the sewer mains, service laterals and appurtenant facilities that collect wastewater from the premises connected thereto for conveyance to a trunk or intercepting sewer. Portions of the trunk and intercepting sewers may function secondarily for the purpose of collection of wastewater from connected premises and are considered as sewer improvements with respect to such connected premises. 
    Special user means any industrial, commercial or institutional user of the treatment works who shall be so classified by the city by reason of the characteristics of the wastes discharged or of the type, extent and nature of the facilities used and required to provide service to such user. 
    Special user surcharge means the additional charge to industries and other users of the treatment works for treatment and disposal of wastewater with characteristics in concentrations greater than normal strength. 
    Standard methods means the analytical procedures set forth in the latest edition of Standard Methods for the Examination of Water and Wastewater, published by the American Public Health Association, or EPA Methods for Chemical Analysis of Water and Wastes, published by the EPA, Water Quality Office, (April 1971) as amended in later editions. 
    Strength of waste means the concentration, expressed in milligrams per liter by weight (mg/l), of a pollutant or substance contained in the liquid waste. 
    Structural component means any part of a building, structure or pipe that is integral to the structural integrity thereof. 
    Substantial completion means that the construction work has been sufficiently completed according to the applicable city, state and federal building and other codes, rules and regulations, so that the owner can occupy or utilize the project for the use for which it is intended. 
    Suspended solids mean the total solid matter that either floats on the surface of or is suspended in water or liquid waste and removable by laboratory filtration. 
    Unpolluted wastewater means and wastewater that is substantially free of pollutants and shall contain, by definition, none of the following: 
(1)  BOD in excess of five milligrams per liter; 
(2)  Suspended solids in excess of five mg/l; 
(3)  Emulsified greases or oils; 
(4)  Acids or alkalies; 
(5)  Phenols or other substances imparting taste or odor in receiving waters; 
(6)  Toxic or poisonous substances; 
(7)  Noxious or odorous gases; 
(8)  Temperature in excess of 150° Fahrenheit. "Unpolluted wastewater" shall also mean any wastewaters determined by the state department of pollution control to be admissible to streams and watercourses under the jurisdiction of such department and according to the standards of water quality established by such department for the particular stream or watercourse into which such unpolluted wastewater is to be discharged. 
    Wastewater means the spent water of the community comprising the liquid and water-carried wastes from residences, commercial buildings, industries and institutions, together with minor quantities of ground and surface waters that are not admitted intentionally. 
    Wastewater disposal charges means the charges made for the conveyance, treatment and disposal of wastewater. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2011-27, § 6, 6-3-2011) 
Sec. 94-67. - Required use of sanitary sewers. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to construct or maintain, within the boundaries of the service area, any privy, privy vault, septic tank, cesspool or other facility intended or used for the disposal of domestic or industrial waste, except where a public sanitary sewer is unavailable as approved by the department. 
(b)  The owner of each lot or parcel of land within the service area that abuts upon a street or other public right-of-way containing a sanitary sewer, upon which lot or parcel one or more buildings have been or shall be constructed for residential, commercial or industrial use, shall connect each building thereon to such sanitary sewer and shall cease to use any other method for the disposal of wastewater. 
(c)  The director has the authority to waive mandatory connection to the public sanitary sewer system where it can be determined that such a connection is not required in the public interest due to public health considerations. 
(d)  If at any time the director finds that a property owner has not made or caused to have been made such connection as required by this section, it shall be the duty of the director to immediately direct such property owner, by notice in writing by United States mail or by hand-delivery, to make or cause to be made such connection within a reasonable time, not to exceed 90 days, from the date of such notification by the director. The director shall have the authority to make or cause to be made such connection, and the cost of making such connection shall become a special assessment lien on the property. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-68. - Excluded wastes. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any person to discharge or deposit any waste, waste material, gases, toxic materials or wastewater that contains any pollutants of a type, nature, temperature or concentration not found in normal domestic wastewater to the collection system. 
(b)  The department sets forth the limitations and types of excluded wastes that may be discharged to the sanitary sewer works. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-69. - Authorization for building sewer connection. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any sanitary sewer or appurtenance thereof without authorization from the department. 
(b)  An application for a building sewer connection and/or service commitment, on a form furnished by the department shall be made by the owner or his agent of any premises to be connected to a sanitary sewer. The application shall be accompanied by any plans, specifications or other pertinent information, including a current Miami-Dade DERM sewer allocation letter. 
(c)  The building sewer connection application shall be approved only after compliance with the applicable provisions in this article. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-70. - Authorization for industrial wastewater discharge permit for an industrial user or special user. 
(a)  It is unlawful for any unauthorized person to uncover, make any connections with or opening into, use, alter or disturb any sanitary sewer or appurtenance thereof without authorization from the department. 
(b)  An industrial wastewater discharge permit application shall be made by the property owner or agent of any premises that is connected or proposed to be connected to a sanitary sewer on a form furnished by the department. The commitment application shall be accompanied by any plans, specifications or other pertinent information. 
(c)  The industrial wastewater discharge permit application may be approved only after compliance with the applicable provisions of this chapter and approval by Miami-Dade DERM. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-71. - Application for sanitary sewer commitment, connection or service; execution of service application considered contract between applicant and city. 
(a)  Anyone requesting a sanitary sewer service commitment or connection shall make application with the department setting forth such information as required by the department. 
(b)  The department shall review such application to determine the adequacy of existing facilities and if new facilities are required. Prior to entering any agreement to extend a sewer force main or lateral, the applicant must secure and have a current sewer allocation letter from DERM. 
(c)  If the department finds it physically and financially feasible to provide service under the usual fee schedules, it will notify the applicant of such determination and issue a commitment or conditional commitment for sanitary sewer service. The commitment or conditional commitment shall specify the point of connection for accepting wastewater from the applicant's project. The applicant thereupon, before the commencement of any work on the project by the department, shall pay to the department the required charges. If the department finds that it is not physically or financially feasible to provide service as requested, it will so notify the applicant and advise what additional charges may be required, or the department may require the applicant to provide the necessary extensions or improvements. If such charges or adjustments are established, the department will issue a conditional commitment for sanitary sewer service. 
(d)  The applicant, upon receipt of the conditional commitment, shall advise the department whether or not the applicant intends to proceed further. If the applicant agrees with the conditions set forth in the department's service commitment and desires to proceed with the project, the applicant shall pay, prior to the issuance of a building permit, the required prevailing wastewater capital charges as determined under section 94-162 as may be existing or proposed to be constructed within the applicant's parcel of land covering the proposed service area. The wastewater capital charges assessed are in addition to sewer improvement service charges, if applicable. 
(e)  All service commitments when issued by the department shall constitute a contract between the applicant and the city that shall bind such applicant to pay the department for the services rendered at its prescribed rates and charges and to comply with all rules and regulations as prescribed and fixed hereunder or as hereafter adopted. 
(f)  If the department approves the application, issues the commitment or conditional commitment and collects the appropriate fees and charges, it will allow the applicant to commence work on the project. 
(g)  The sanitary sewer commitment shall become invalid if a building permit has not been issued after one year and/or after the expiration of the Miami-Dade sewer allocation letter, whichever date is earlier. In addition, the sanitary sewer commitment shall become invalid if the work authorized by the building permit is not commenced within six months after date of issuance of the building permit, unless extended, or the project is abandoned for a period of one year after the work is commenced. An extension for a commitment shall be in writing. No sewer connection will be permitted unless the customer is also connecting to the water system. 
(h)  All commitments, when paid by the customer or upon the department's performance of the service, shall constitute a contract between the customer and the city that shall bind the customer to all conditions of the commitment and will require the customer to comply with all the rules and regulations as prescribed and fixed hereunder or as hereafter adopted. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2011-27, § 6, 6-3-2011) 
Sec. 94-72. - Extensions or improvements provided by applicant. 
(a)  If the conditional commitment requires the applicant to provide the necessary extensions or improvements to serve the project, the applicant shall be responsible for design, construction and inspection according to the city's sewer standards and specifications as approved by the department. 
(b)  The applicant is responsible for retaining a Florida licensed engineer to prepare the design of the improvements. The construction drawings shall be signed and sealed by an engineer currently registered in the state and are to be submitted to the department for review and approval. Construction of the sewer improvements or extensions shall not commence until the department approves the engineer's construction drawings. Following approval of the construction drawings, the applicant may proceed towards the installation of the improvements. The applicant is responsible for retaining a utility contractor who is licensed to perform the installation and approved by the department prior to commencement of work. If the improvements or extensions are to be constructed in public rights-of-way or approved easements, the applicant and/or the applicant's engineer or contractor shall be responsible for securing all necessary permits. 
(c)  The applicant or contractor prior to commencing construction shall have sufficient liability insurance coverage to protect the public and shall hold the city and department harmless from any claim against personal injury or property damage that is caused by the contractor throughout the duration of the construction until such time as the department approves the completed improvements or extensions. 
(d)  The applicant is responsible for retaining a Florida licensed engineer to supervise the construction and to furnish as-built drawings to the department following completion of construction. The department has authorization to withhold approval of a certificate of occupancy for the applicant's project if the improvements have not been completed to the department's standards and specifications or the as-built drawings have not been submitted. 
(e)  All improvements or extensions constructed in the public right-of-way or approved easements, when completed by the applicant to the department's satisfaction, shall be conveyed to the city at not cost to the city. The applicant shall execute a conveyance in a form acceptable to the city. In conveying the improvements, the applicant-owner shall guarantee the improvements against any defects in workmanship and materials for a period of one year following the date of the agreement. Prior to acceptance and approval of the improvements, the city shall inspect the improvement via television camera. The department has authorization to withhold approval of certificate of occupancy for the applicant's project and/or terminate the service commitment if the applicant fails to execute the agreement. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-73. - Costs, sizes and methods of construction for building sewer connection. 
(a)  The property owner shall pay all costs and expenses incidental to the installation and connection of the building sewer. The property owner shall indemnify the city from any loss or damage that may be caused by the installation of the building sewer. 
(b)  The city shall provide a separate and independent service lateral for each lot or parcel of land up to the property line of the lot or parcel closest to the sewers. The property owner shall provide a two-way cleanout at the property line. The property owner shall provide a separate and independent building sewer for every building on each lot or parcel of land, except where one building stands at the rear of another on an interior lot and no private sewer is available or can be constructed to the rear building through an adjoining alley, court, yard or driveway. In such circumstances, the building sewer serving the front building may be extended to the rear building, but the city will not assume any obligation or responsibility for operation, maintenance, repair or damage caused by or resulting from any such connection of two buildings to a single building sewer. 
(c)  Old building sewers may be used in connection with new buildings only if the old sewers meet current plumbing code requirements. 
(d)  The size, slope, alignment, materials of construction of a building sewer and the methods to be used in excavating, placing of the pipe, jointing, testing and backfilling the trench shall comply with all applicable city code and department requirements, rules and regulations. The materials and procedures set forth in appropriate specifications of the Miami-Dade Water and Sewer Department shall apply, if the city does not provide any standards. 
(e)  The connection of the building sewer into the service lateral shall conform to all applicable city codes and requirements or the procedures set forth herein. All such connections, verified by proper testing, shall be made watertight. Before installation, the director must approve any deviation from the prescribed procedures and materials. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-74. - Alternate materials and methods of construction. 
    The provisions of this article are not intended to prevent the use of any material or method of construction not specifically prescribed by this article, unless the city approves an alternate. The department shall approve any such alternate, provided it finds that the alternate for the purpose intended is at least the equivalent of that prescribed in this article in quality, strength, effectiveness, performance, durability and safety. The department shall require that sufficient evidence or proof certified by Florida licensed professional engineer be submitted to substantiate any claim made regarding the alternate. The department reserves the right to deny a request to use alternative construction materials or methods if the criteria set forth herein are not met. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-75. - Construction standards adopted. 
    The city standards for sanitary sewers are adopted by reference. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Secs. 94-76-94-90. - Reserved. 
ARTICLE IV. - PROCEDURES FOR WATER AND SEWER SERVICES 
DIVISION 1. - APPLICATION PROCESS 

Sec. 94-91. - Application for services; responsibility for payment of bills. 
(a)  All customers requesting city utility services, connection to utility lines of the city or commitment for such services shall make application to the department therefore setting forth information required by the city. The department shall determine the order, sequence and requirements for making applications. 
(b)  The customer shall be responsible for any debts created by the customer or the customer's agent or authorized representative. The customer shall be responsible for payments of utility bills until the city has received the customer's written cancellation notice. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2007-039, § 1, 4-10-2007) 
Sec. 94-92. - Application and contract. 
(a)  The property owner shall fully complete all information requested by the city on an application form supplied by the city. 
(b)  The property owner or its agent or representative, if such authorization is submitted in writing, shall sign the application for water and sewer service, except as hereinafter provided. 
(c)  Such application shall become a binding contract upon both the property owner and the city when the service connection for water supply service has been installed and completed. Prior to the installation and completion of such service connection, the property owner may cancel or withdraw the application made, upon his written order, after payment to the city of the actual cost and expense incurred by the city in connection therewith. 
(d)  All contracts for water supply service shall expire at the end of the next succeeding calendar month from date of application, but all contracts shall continue in force by renewal without act or notice from either party to the other, from month to month, unless ten days written notice is given by either party to the other of the party's intent to terminate the contract at the expiration of the calendar month The charging for and payment of utility bills bi-monthly, or in any manner, and for any interval or period, other than bi-monthly, shall not be constructed as altering the period of the contract or any renewal thereof under this subsection. 
(e)  If there is any change in ownership or occupancy of any premises connected to the system, the department shall be immediately notified in writing of such change, identifying the name and address of the new owner or occupant. In the absence of such application by such new owner or occupant, the use of the city's service may, at the option of the department, be taken and construed to be an acceptance by such new owner or occupant of all the contract obligations of the preceding owner with the city. If any owner fails to notify the city in writing of a change in ownership or occupancy of any premises for water supply service, such property owner shall continue to be liable to the city for all rates and charges accrued and accruing for such service until either the end of the contract period in which the property owner may later notify the city of its intent to cancel, or the city shall, of its own volition, have canceled the contract with the property owner; but this shall not preclude the city from also demanding from the new owner or occupant the payment of all or any charges and rates that shall at the time of such demand be unpaid or unsecured, without regard to whether the same accrued prior or subsequent to such change in ownership or occupancy; and upon failure of such new owner to comply with such demand within 72 hours after written notice thereof, the city shall have the right to shut off the water supply and discontinue its service. Change of ownership shall not release the preceding owner from any contractual obligations with the city until the expiration of the contract period, properly terminated according to this chapter, except at the city's option. 
(f)  When application for water supply service is made, the service, together with the charges and rates thereof, shall begin on the date of the completion of the service connection by the city, unless the owner shall state in writing in the application that such service connection shall be shut off immediately upon its installation, in which event the connection shall be shut-off, and shall thereafter be turned on by the city only upon written request of the property owner, and the charges and rates for water supply service shall commence from date of the turning on of service as though such request had been an original application. Whenever there shall have been a change in ownership prior to turning on the service connection, the new property owner must sign the application for water service. 
(g)  All the foregoing rates and rules shall be considered and taken to be part of the contract, so far as the same may be applicable to the class of service covered by and included in such contract, with every property owner who shall make application for the water supply service or whose premises are furnished with, or are connected to the system of the city for such service; and every such owner shall be considered as having and be taken and construed to have expressed consent to be bound thereby whenever application for such water supply service is made, or so long as the premises of any such owner is furnished with, or is connected to the city's system for such service. 
(h)  Upon the death of a property owner who has made a guarantee of payment deposit for a residential single-family dwelling or apartment or condominium unit and where the surviving owner has a homestead claim, transfer or a guarantee of payment deposit is allowed to continue service if such surviving owner who can show proof of joint ownership or joint occupancy during the period in which the water supply service was in effect for the premises. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-93. - Cancellation of contract and discontinuance of service. 
    The department reserves the right to cancel service contracts and discontinue service for the following reasons: 
(a)  For misrepresentations or concealment in the application as to the premises or fixtures to be furnished with water supply service, or the use to be made of such service. 
(b)  For waste or excessive use of water through improper or imperfect pipes, fixtures or appliances or in any other manner. 
(c)  For refusal or neglect to make any advance payment, if such is required by the department, or for refusal or neglect to comply with any requirement of the department as to meter or service connection maintenance, alteration or renewal or other requirement relating to the water supply service of the city. 
(d)  For the use of water supply service for or in connection with or for the benefit of any other premises or purpose than identified or described in the application. 
(e)  For any interference or tampering with the meter measuring the water supply, or with seals of any meter, or with any meter box or vault, or with service pipes, or valves or any seals thereon, or with the curb stopcock, or with any appliance of the department or with any appliance of the property owner, which was or is required by the department for controlling or regulating the water supply service; and for the purpose of this subsection any interference or tampering with any appliance used in connecting with or for controlling or regulating the water supply service to any premises shall be construed and taken to be the act of the property owner or consumer using water service at the premises. 
(f)  For continued vacancy of the premises. 
(g)  For material violation of any rule and regulation of the department. 
(h)  Where there has been a change in ownership of the premises, but no application from the new owner has been made and approved by the department. 
(i)  Where there has been a discontinuance of the use of water service. 
(j)  Where the property owner has terminated the contract. 
(k)  Where a property owner or consumer refuses or fails to pay a bill, account or charge, by whomsoever incurred, for or on account of the premises where the water supply is furnished, after notice is provided by the city to the property owner or consumer and given an opportunity to pay as provided herein. 
(l)  Where the department has been or is being defrauded in any way. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-94. - Acceptance of provisions. 
    No water service will be furnished to any person in the city who does not agree to accept all of the provisions contained in this chapter, and all rules and regulations not inconsistent herewith promulgated by the department for the regulation of water and/or sewer service. The acceptance of water and/or sewer services from the city shall be, in itself, the acceptance of all provisions hereof. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Secs. 94-95-94-105. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 2. - METERING AND REMETERING 

Sec. 94-106. - Number of units per meter connection. 
    Not more than one such house or principal building with its adjacent accessory buildings located upon the same premises shall be furnished with water from the same meter, except that this provision is not meant to apply as to group housing, composed of two or more separate buildings under single ownership and deemed to be a single premises. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-107. - Unauthorized connections. 
    It is unlawful for any person to tamper with or change, or make any connection with the water system or sewer system of the water and sewer system without the written consent of the city, or to make any reconnection with the water and sewer system or any part thereof when service has been discontinued for delinquent charges until all such delinquent charges have been paid in full, including late fees, interest and administrative fees and costs, as defined by the department. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-108. - Access to meters. 
    The agents or employees of the city shall have access at all times to meters, connections and automatic reading and billing devices, and shall have the license to enter upon the premises of the customer for all reasonable purposes connected with billing and service and to disconnect service for the nonpayment of bills when due or to remove the meter for any default on the part of the customer. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-109. - Meter tests. 
    If any customer is not satisfied with the meter reading and requests the city to test the meter, the city shall test such meter. If it is found that the meter is registering correctly, the customer shall pay a service charge. If the meter did not register correctly within a threshold of a ten percent range of discrepancy, the customer shall not be required to pay any sum for testing the meter. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-110. - Tampering with meters, other apparatus. 
    It shall be unlawful for any unauthorized person to tamper with or break a water meter or the seal and/or lock thereof, turn curb or corporation cocks, or molest in any manner whatsoever any apparatus used and owned by the city in connection with its water system. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-111. - Metered water supply service. 
(a)  The department shall furnish and install all meters at its own expense, upon the application of any customer paying for the use of such meter a monthly minimum service charge and all meters so furnished and installed shall be and remain the property of the city subject to the city's absolute and exclusive control. 
(b)  In every instance of metered supply service, the customer shall provide and maintain a location for the meter, acceptable to the department. A customer shall not change the location of a meter once installed except if the city grants permission subject to payment of relocation costs. If any customer makes any change in is premises, which in the discretion of the department requires any change in the location or position of the meter or meter box, such change in location or position shall be made by the department at the cost and expense of the customer. 
(c)  Repairs, renewals and replacement of all water meters, meter boxes, with connections and appliances, shall be made by the department at its own expense where such repairs, renewals and replacement are due to the ordinary wear and tear of service. 
(d)  Reading of meters shall be taken as near as practicable to produce a similar service period for each billing, and if the meter is in good order and has been in good condition during the time since the last previous reading, bills shall be rendered in accordance therewith. 
(e)  All meters shall be carefully tested before installation, and after installation, such meters shall be tested as frequently as circumstances seem to the department to warrant. If the customer questions the accuracy of the meter servicing his property, the department shall, once during a 12-month period upon his written application, accompanied with a payment of $25.00 for each meter, to defray the cost of test thereof, remove the meter and test it in the presence of the customer or his authorized agent, if such presence is desired by the customer. If the test shows that the meter has been over-registering (positive result) more than ten percent, the testing cost for each meter so paid shall be credited to customer, and the bill rendered, based on the last reading of such meter, shall be corrected accordingly. If the test shows that the meter is not over-registering more than ten percent (negative result) the testing cost paid by the customer shall be retained by the department and in addition thereto, if the test shows that the meter has been under-registering more than the ten percent, the bill rendered, based on the last reading of such meter, shall be corrected accordingly. The department reserves the right to remove and test any meter at any time, and if such meter is found to be inaccurate, to substitute another meter of the same size in its place, either permanently or temporarily. The department further reserves the right to make any correction in the bill rendered based on the last reading of such meter, according to test results. If a second request for an accuracy test is submitted during the 12-month period there shall be a $90.00 application fee, which will be credited if the test results are positive. No credits will be granted where negative test results are found. The test procedures described in this section shall be followed on all retests together with payment of the application fee. 
(f)  The quantity of water recorded by the meter shall be conclusive on both the customer and the department except when the meter has been found to be defective or ceases to register. If the meter has been found to be defective or has ceased to register, the quantity of water supplied since the last reading shall be determined by the average registration of another meter for a period of 60 days, or of the same meter for a like period after it has been repaired and tested; or by mutual agreement the quantity of water supplied may be prorated upon the previous corresponding period from the date of the last reading preceding the time the meter has been or become defective or has failed to register to the time such meter is repaired or replaced. 
(g)  If a customer has an outstanding balance due over 30 calendar days and the customer has not made proper arrangements with the department to pay the outstanding balance upon written notice to the customer and the customer given an opportunity to pay within 30 days or agree to pay the outstanding balance through a payment plan acceptable to the city, the department may remove the meter and plug the line unless the customer pays the outstanding balance, including the cost of the removal and reinstallation of the meter and the plug. 
(h)  The customer shall pay to the department, in addition to the cost of the services, the sum of $100.00 for each meter for each time the seal on any meter or its couplings on or for such premises if the customer has broken or removed the seal or its couplings, the department hereby reserving the right to put on such seals in or for any premises at any time; and upon the second occurrence of such violation, the department may, at its option, shut off the supply, remove the meter and discontinue its service, and may further refuse to again turn on the same and resume its service to such premises so long as the customer at the premises at the time of the breaking or removal of such seal shall continue to be the customer at the premises. 
(i)  A customer may request that the department verify a reading if the customer has specific reason to believe that the actual reading taken is in error. If the department at the customer's request establishes that the reading taken is correct, the customer shall pay the department a fee of $25.00 for such services. If it is concluded that the reading is in error, the customer will not be charged for this service and the bill will be adjusted accordingly. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-112. - Meter-Temporary use. 
(a)  If a number of residences are supplied through one meter and one service, if at any time one or more of such residences are sold, transferred, or otherwise passes under separate ownership, the customer shall be required to disconnect such residences and have separate meters installed for each separate location. 
(b)  Where the customer of a building containing more than one store, dwelling or other premises desires that separate meters be installed to each separate store, dwelling or other premises, such additional meters shall be installed upon the payment in advance, by the customer, of the regular tapping charge for a new service for each meter installed. 
(c)  Contractors and other people will be supplied with water for temporary use according to the regular service charges as provided for water supply, provided that all fees for the subject property have been paid in full through the last billing cycle or, if no account has been previously established, that such account is established. Such contractors or others shall be required to deposit regular guarantee of payment deposit. Such deposit shall be held by the department as a guarantee of safety for the meter and other equipment of the department furnished the contractor, and for the payment of charges for water used through the meter. The customer shall be charged the regular tapping charge for the cost of making the tap, setting the meter and other expenses in connection therewith, and for the removal of the meter and connections. Upon payment of all charges and the removal and discontinuance of service through the meter, the department shall refund the unencumbered amount of the deposit made by the customer for such service. 
(d)  Contractors or any other consumer desiring water for temporary use shall not be allowed to use water from fire hydrants. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-113. - Remetering of water services and reselling water. 
    Owners of multiple-unit properties may recover the costs of water and sewer services from individual units through the measurement of usage by submeters placed on a water line by private vendors after the department's master meter. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-114. - Remetering-Definitions. 
    The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this chapter, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    Master meter means a meter used to measure all water service usage in a multi-unit development, including, but not limited to, individual units, common areas, and recreational areas and architectural features utilizing, water. 
    Multi-unit development means property consisting of two or more units served by a single master meter, including, but not limited to, apartments, condominiums, townhouses, mobile home parks, shopping centers and industrial warehouses. 
    Remeters means to resell water service to a multi-unit development by using a private submeter at a rate and charges that does not exceed the rate and charges billed by the city to the owner/customer or managing agent. 
    Submeter means the meter serving an individual unit of a multi-unit development that is installed on the outlet side of the master meter for the purpose of measuring and reading water service consumption of the individual unit. 
    Water service means the water and/or sewer provided by the department of water and sewers. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-115. - Remetering service. 
(a)  If a property owner or customer of a multi-unit development requests to remeter and install and operate submeters, the city may install and maintain its submeters, at the sole cost and expense of the property owner or customer, but only if subject to written agreement, signed by the property owner or customer and the city, approved by the city council. If a property owner or customer desires to install and operate submeters for monitoring individual unit water consumption, without charging the individual units based on the reading of the submeters, then the city may approve the installation and operation of private submeters, subject to these rules and regulations. All owners or customers who remeter, install or cause to install and operate submeters shall comply with all departmental rules and regulations concerning submeters. 
(b)  Property owners or customers, who desire to remeter a multiple unit development, are hereby required to enter into a written agreement with the city, approved by the city council. The approved agreements shall provide the terms and conditions of the continued operation and use of private submeters until such time that the installation costs of the private submeters have been amortized as determined by the department director. Upon an amortization date not exceeding five years from the installation date of a private submeter used to remeter, the property owner or customer shall remove such private meters from operation unless the five-year period is extended by mutual consent. 
(c)  Property owners or customers that have remetered their multiple unit developments shall charge residents the same water and sewer consumption rates as those charged by the city. It is unlawful to resell water service at a consumption rate and charge in excess of city water services rates and charges billed to city property owners or customers. 
(d)  The agreements may allow the continued operation of private submeters subject to compliance with departmental rules and regulations, including semi-annual reporting and city review of water billing records. Alternatively, the agreements may allow for the cost of the installation of the meters, including permitting costs, to be amortized for a period not exceeding five years from the effective date of the agreement and upon the expiration of the amortization period, the city may assume the operation and maintenance of the private meters with licensed contractors, depending on the circumstances. If an agreement allows for the continued operation of the private submeters, the city may renew the agreement if the property owner or customer has not resold water at rates higher than city rates and has not charged administrative fees representing additional costs to individual tenants or unit owners. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-116. - Submetering. 
    As of July 1, 2008, the city shall require individual submeters for water service for each individual dwelling unit for multiple-family residential developments. 
(Ord. No. 2008-26, § 1, 4-8-2008) 
Secs. 94-117-94-125. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 3. - DEPOSITS, FEES, BILLS, PAYMENTS 

Sec. 94-126. - Deposits-Generally. 
(a)  Any person making application for water service shall pay an applicable deposit prior to commencement of water service. The city may bill the transfer charge and turn-on charge to accounts for buildings with an existing installation. 
(b)  Deposits may be transferred upon application by an existing residential or commercial customer for the same service at a new address within the city's service area and payment of a transfer charge, and turn-on charge that may be billed, if required, as long as the account is current and in good standing. 
(c)  Deposits from all utility customers shall be made and maintained with the department. Deposits must be paid in advance. The city may increase any such required deposit whenever such increase shall be deemed necessary by the city to guarantee payment of future bills of the customer, or on the services requested by the customer. 
(d)  The deposit shall be held by the city and will be applied to the final bill of the customer's account upon termination of the account. The total amount of the deposit shall be applied first to pay outstanding interest, administrative charges and late fees, and then the outstanding balance of water and/or sewer charges. 
(e)  When an account has been terminated and the deposit or balance thereof shall be unclaimed by the person entitled to receive the deposit, disposition shall be according to state law. The city shall not pay interest to customers on deposits held by the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-127. - Same-Interest. 
    The city shall retain the actual interest the city earns on each of the utility customer's accounts for which there is a deposit. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-128. - Billing. 
(a)  The department shall send utility bills to customers every two months (bi-monthly), or such billing cycles as determined by the department, and such bills will be based on rates and charges set forth by city council resolution and all ordinances relating to the furnishing of the city's utility services. 
(b)  Charges shall be made to a water and/or sanitary sewer customer based upon a determination of water usage made by reading the water meter provided to the premises of that customer. 
(c)  Whenever reading of the water meter on a bi-monthly basis is not provided, the city shall have the authority to bill a customer for water and/or sewer charges on an average estimated basis as determined herein. 
(d)  At the discretion of the city, the bi-monthly bill may include any rate, fee or charge prescribed for services as provided in this chapter. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-129. - Utility bills-When due and payable. 
(a)  All bills for utility services are due and payable when rendered. 
(b)  Bills shall be sent to customer's bi-monthly and the fact that a customer does not receive a bill shall not relieve such customer of the customer's obligation to pay for such services. 
(c)  A utility bill shall not be considered paid until remittance for the utility bill has been received and recorded in the accounts receivable records of the department. But in no event later than three working days upon receipt. 
(d)  Payment of all utility bills maybe made to the department's cashier in the department of water and sewers or by mail addressed to the department. 
(e)  To avoid late penalties, all water and sewer utility bills shall be paid within 30 days from the date of the bill. A ten percent late charge shall be added to all water and sewer utility bills, if not paid within 30 days from the date on the bill. 
(f)  The postmark date of a mailed payment shall not be considered as the date of payment. 
(g)  No abatements or deductions on metered service charges shall be made or allowed, except for errors in meter readings on which such charges are based, or inaccuracies in the registration of any meter, or because of error on the part of the department in the making of any charges or in the amount thereof, and then only provided claim for such abatement or deduction is made in writing within the 30 days after the date of the disputed bill. 
(h)  No abatements or deductions on any bill or charge rendered or made by the department for any service or purpose other than metered service shall be made or allowed unless and only when claim for such abatements or deductions is made in writing within 30 days after the date of the disputed bill. 
(i)  Dishonored checks will be automatically represented to the banks for collection; and if returned for whatever reason, the account will be charged a fee as set forth by the city. 
(j)  The department may issue one itemized water and/or sewer utility bill, where practicable, for all water meters billed to a property owner or customer on a particular parcel of property. 
(k)  Where an account is turned off for nonpayment, if the guaranty deposit that has been paid by the customer at the time of application for water service is less than the current required deposit fee, the customer shall be required to pay an additional deposit to equal the current required deposit plus all outstanding balances and reconnection fees. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-130. - Same-Delinquent after 30 days; discontinuance of services; refusal of service. 
(a)  A utility bill shall be delinquent if not paid within 30 days after the billing date. Late penalties shall be charged after 30 days. If payment is not received or agreement to pay the bill within 30 days under a payment plan acceptable to the city, and after an additional 30 days after the date written notice is sent to the customer, service shall be discontinued, the meter removed and the service line plugged, and the unpaid bill charged against the deposit. 
(b)  The city shall have authority to refuse utility service to a customer until such time as the bill is paid in full, unless the customer disputes the bill in writing within 30 days of the date of the bill. The city shall provide the customer an administrative hearing to resolve the dispute. The city shall have the authority to transfer a delinquent bill to any other account that is in the customer's name; provided, however, this section shall not be constructed to permit the city to refuse or discontinue service to a customer for nonpayment of utility bills by a former occupant of the same property, except to the extent that the customer benefited directly from the service provided to the former occupant. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-131. - Delinquent accounts; payment of collection costs and attorney fees; creation of liens. 
(a)  All bills and accounts rendered and charges made by the city's utility billing system in arrears as provided in this article shall be termed delinquent accounts. The owner and/or customer of any premises supplied by water and/or sewer utility services by the city shall pay all costs of collection, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney's fees, incurred at the trial, administrative and appellate levels. 
(b)  All delinquent accounts, including metered water supply and/or sewer utility service, shall be discontinued and the water supply shut off from and to the premises of the owner or customer from whom such account is in the arrears as provided herein, regardless of the status of the property owner's other accounts. A disconnect charge as provided by administrative order of the mayor shall be assessed against such owner or customer and the water not turned on to any premises until a turn-on fee as provided by administrative order of the mayor has been paid in full. 
(c)  When an owner or customer vacates or sells property leaving a delinquent bill in the name of the owner or customer, the department may, at its option, refuse to open a new water and/or sewer account at another location within the city service area to the same owner or customer for use in the future until the date of the original delinquent account is paid, regardless of whether the other accounts of the owner or customer are in good standing. 
(d)  When water and/or sewer utility services are furnished to the owner of any premises, the charges for such services shall be and constitute a lien against the premises, and shall become effective and binding as such lien from the date upon which the account becomes due, unpaid and in arrears. Existing liens and liens imposed hereafter as set out in this subsection shall be treated as special assessment liens against the subject real property, and until fully paid and discharged, shall remain liens equal in rank and dignity with the lien of ad valorem taxes, and shall be superior in rank and dignity to all other liens, encumbrances, titles and claims in, to or against the real property involved; the legal rate of interest shall accrue to such delinquent accounts. Such liens for service charges and penalties shall be enforced by any of the methods provided in F.S. ch. 86; or, in the alternative, foreclosure proceedings may be instituted and prosecuted under the provisions applicable to practice, pleading and procedure for the foreclosure of mortgages on real estate set forth in state law, or may be foreclosed per F.S. ch. 173 or F.S. § 159.17, if applicable; or the collection and enforcement of payment thereof may be accomplished by any other method authorized by law. The owner and/or customer shall pay all costs of collection, including, but not limited to, reasonable attorney's fees, incurred at the trial, administrative and appellate levels. The remedy provided in this subsection shall be cumulative and shall not be construed to waive the right of the city to require payment of any bill in arrears before renewing any services of the department to the premises. 
(e)  When water supply has been shut off from and to the premises of the owner or customer from whom such account is in arrears, and the water supply is found to have been turned on by other than authorized department personnel, a charge shall be assessed against such owner or customer for the unauthorized usage of the city water supply. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2007-039, § 1, 4-10-2007) 
Sec. 94-132. - Service of notices. 
    Any notices prescribed in this article shall be deemed to have been properly served if left upon the premises of the owner or if mailed to the owner, directed to, or left at the service address as shown on records of the water and sewers department or address of owner, if different from the service address, if the owner provides such address to the water and sewer department. All notices of a general character affecting or likely to affect more than one owner, if required by this article to be given, shall be deemed to have been properly given or served if advertised at least once in a daily newspaper of general circulation within the county, including the neighborhood section covering the city. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-133. - Effect of amendments to rates and rules. 
    Every addition or modification, alteration or amendment to any of the rates or rules of the department shall be and become binding upon, and shall form a part of the contract with every owner, upon the expiration of 30-day period after proper notice thereof in writing is given to every owner affected thereby. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-134. - Billing and collection of charges. 
    All water and sewer bills and notices shall be delivered to customers by such means and shall be for such period of service as shall be determined by the department. 
(a)  Every water and sewer customer shall have the right to have any disputed or suspected erroneous water and sewer billing reviewed by the city. The director shall designate such employees to hear customer disputes and adjust bills and shall make at least one such employee available to water and sewer customers during regular office hours and such other times as the director deems necessary and appropriate. If the customer is not satisfied with the disposition of the matter made by the city, the customer shall have the right to appeal that disposition to the director. 
(b)  New customers requesting service shall be rendered a bill for the first billing cycle during which service is requested, reflecting the actual gallons used and a capacity and customer charge, based on the actual number of the days of service provided in the initial billing cycle; provided, that where it is established that a customer and capacity charge for service has been collected pursuant to a final bill rendered and paid by the prior customer during the initial billing period, the new customer shall not be billed a duplicate customer and capacity charge for the initial billing period. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-135. - Turnoffs and meter removals. 
(a)  Application; customer liability for service rendered. Applications to discontinue water and sewer service, either by turnoff or removal of the meter, shall be made to the department. The customer shall be responsible for all water consumed to the date of discontinuation and for five business days thereafter to allow the city to read the meter. 
(b)  Billing for service rendered. When the customer requests turnoff or removal of the meter, the meter shall be read within five business days and a final bill rendered consisting of the sum of the following charges: 
a.  The bi-monthly customer charge for water service; 
b.  The bi-monthly capacity charge for water service; 
c.  The bi-monthly commodity charge for all water consumed; 
d.  The bi-monthly sewer charge; 
e.  The bi-monthly M-DDERM fee; 
f.  The bi-monthly utility tax. 
(c)  Temporary turnoffs, removals. Temporary turnoffs or meter removals are prohibited. However, a customer may request a turnoff or meter removal for safety while the property served is to be vacant, upon payment of the applicable fee, but the customer shall be billed during the turnoff or removal period, in addition to the final billing as provided above, a bimonthly water customer charge and capacity charge and bimonthly sewer charge for each bimonthly billing period. 
(d)  Transfer of accounts. When a customer requests an account transfer, a fee as established by administrative order shall be charged for each transfer, provided water service is on. 
(1)  Where water service had been turned off, the turn-on fee shall be assessed. 
(2)  Where the water meter had been physically removed, a reconnection charge shall be assessed. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-136. - Automatic reading and billing devices. 
    The department and its employees and agents may enter upon any real property receiving or requesting water or sewer services hereunder and install under the ground and upon the exterior of any building or structure located thereon an automatic meter reading and billing device. The property owner shall be notified prior to such installation. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Secs. 94-137-94-150. - Reserved. 
DIVISION 4. - RATES, FEES AND CHARGES 

Sec. 94-151. - Schedule of water rates and tapping charges. 
(a)  Every water supply service shall have a minimum service charge on each service installed, varying with and based upon the size of the meter required and installed according to departmental rules and regulations. This minimum charge shall be established by ordinance and shall entitle the consumer to have supplied through the meter the number of gallons of water as described by ordinance. There shall not be a rental charge on meters. 
(b)  For quantities of water supplied in excess of the amount set forth in subsection (a) of this section based on the particular size of the meter, the water rates shall be as specified by ordinance, which rates shall be prorated for each 100 gallons. 
(c)  On all water supply service, each bi-monthly billing cycle shall be a complete period in itself, and no excess consumption of water during period shall be charged against the minimum service charge or be added to the consumption of any other period. 
(d)  Pre-pay program. The provisions contained in subsection (c) shall not apply to a customer of a single-family home that participates in the budget billing or pre-pay program of department. The pre-pay program allows owners to pre-pay the annual estimated water and sewer consumption based on the average of the previous annual consumption history and to obtain a discount in an amount not to exceed five percent of the estimated amount. If the variance in actual consumption becomes more than 20 percent of the annual consumption average, the budgeted amount would be recalculated or the budget billing would cease and regular billing would commence. To be eligible for the pre-pay program, the owner would have to submit an application to the department for budget billing. After the approval of the department, the budget billing would commence and would only cease upon written request by the owner or the failure to pay the budget amount when the payment is due. Only owners whose accounts are in good standing may participate in budget billing. 
(e)  Upon the application of the customer for water service on the premises to which there has not been made any previous service for water, tapping charges shall be assessed to cover the cost of the tap and the installation of the service to the property line of the lot to be supplied with water service. 
(f)  Every customer making an application for water service shall be required to make a deposit with the department called a guarantee of payment deposit. The amount of such deposit shall be according to the size of the service. If the customer making such deposit wishes the service to be discounted, the guarantee of payment deposit shall be refunded less outstanding charges for water and/or sewer and interest. If at any time the total service charges for a given account exceed the amount of the deposit, the city reserves the right to demand an additional deposit up to four times the amount of any previous utility bill on that service. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005) 
Sec. 94-152. - Sanitary sewer service charge. 
    A sanitary sewer service charge shall be assessed upon all premises within the city connected to or using the facilities of the city's sanitary sewer system. Such sanitary sewer service charge shall be in an amount established by ordinance. The amount of such sanitary sewer service charge shall be included in such water bills and shall be paid by the customer at the same time and in the same manner as is provided in this article for the payment of water bills. 
(Ord. No. 2005-57, § 1, 6-28-2005; Ord. No. 2011-27, § 7, 6-3-2011) 
Sec. 94-153. - Utility rates, fees and charges. 
(a)  Free service. There shall be no free service rendered for any utility service provided by the city. All accounts shall have a deposit. 
(b)  Authority to establish. The city council shall have the authority to set rates, fees and charges by ordinance, including wastewater capital charges as provided in this section. 
(c)  Annual consumer price index adjustment of water and sewer rates. That each October 1 from and after October 1, 2006, the latest water and sewer charges shall be adjusted by the amount of the annual increase in the index numbers of retail commodity prices designated "Consumer Price Index For All Urban Consumers-United States City Average-All items (the "Consumer Price Index" or "CPI") as issued by the Bureau of Labor Statistics, United States Department of Labor. The annual CPI increase provided in this subsection shall not be applicable or effective unless and until the city complies with the notification procedures of F.S. § 180.136, as applicable, and confirms such increase in rates and charges by ordinance of the city council. 
(d)  Types of fees. Fees will be charged for the following services and costs: 
(1)  Day turn-on and account start-up fee; 
(2)  Removal of curb lock; 
(3)  Broken curb lock; 
(4)  Bad check handling charge; 
(5)  Bad check charge if cut off; 
(6)  Delinquent account collection charge; 
(7)  Delinquent account charge if cut off; 
(8)  Emergency turn-on/off at owner's request. The turn-on fee will be charged for each trip made by a meter service attendant. Service will not be left on when the meter indicates an open valve or faucet; 
(9)  Labor and material costs incurred by the city due to damage to its property. 
(10)  Reconnection charges. 
(e)  Water rates. The rates for water furnished by the city to the customer shall be based upon the quantity of water, determined by metering, furnished to each premises each billing period including the minimum monthly charges. Different rates are to be charged to premises inside and outside the city limits in accordance with section 94-158. A surcharge for service provided outside the territorial limits of the city is assessed as set forth in section 94-158. 
(f)  Water rates, fees and charges. 
(1)  All water used, other than for the prevention and extinguishment of fires or for testing of fire hydrants, by the city itself or by any other political subdivision or public agency, except as otherwise provided in any contract between the city and a public agency for supplying water at special rates to any agency, shall be paid for at meter measurement at the rates hereinafter established by resolution or by approval of annual budget. 
(2)  The city shall pay the department an annual fire hydrant charge, as established by resolution. 
(3)  Revenues received for water furnished to the city shall be applied and accounted for in the same manner as other revenues derived from the operation of the waterworks system of the city. 
(g)  Water installation charges, capital charges and other fees. The following charges pertain to installation or capital and other fees and charges for services performed by the water department. 
(1)  Installation charges (to be paid prior to the installation). 
a.  Installation charges for five-eighths-inch by three-fourths-inch through two-inch water meters. 
b.  Installation charges for meters larger than two inches. 
c.  Installation charges for irrigation and hydrant meters shall be computed separately. 
d.  If the flow rate requirement in subsection (g)(1)c. (above) is greater than customer's existing service capacity, the customer shall require a new service with adequate capacity and shall pay a new installation charge, plus additional appropriate water capital charges. 
e.  Installation charges for fire protection system connection assemblies shall be computed separately for each size and location. 
f.  Additional charges shall be assessed to the customer for costs incurred due to extraordinary or special condition that include, but are not limited to, requirements for casing, meter vaults and remote meter reading devices. 
g.  New water customers who desire to have immediate meter service installations at a time when it is found and determined by the director to be physically impossible to provide such immediate installation may file an application for permission to have a qualified licensed contractor perform the meter service installation. The customer's contractor will furnish and install the complete service with the exception of the meter, which will be installed by the department, and that only the department, may make those meter service installations. The customer will be responsible for all charges for repair to the meter service installation for one year after the installation is accepted by the city. Upon primary acceptance by the department, all meters, however installed, shall be the sole property of the city and shall constitute part of the water distribution system of the city. Contractors performing this work must be certified as to expertise by the department, use only department-approved materials and install the services according to departmental standards. Contractor's minimum certification requirements include, but are not limited to, furnishing proof of insurance protecting the city in the amount and coverage acceptable to the risk manager; providing a bond in the amount of $5,000.00 to protect against all claims, suits or actions. 
h.  The department may reinstall a service of the same size and turn-on at curb stop, if the service meets the department's standards. If it does not, the customer will be charged all costs necessary to restore the service to the departmental standards and the payment of a new service installation charge. 
(2)  Applications for water service are subject to appropriate water capital charges contained in Sec. 94-162, which must be paid by the customers of such property to the department before the department makes the connection. 
(3)  Fire protection system capital charges charged shall be established by ordinance. Such capital charges shall be paid by all users located outside the city territorial limits and for new construction within the city. 
(4)  Miscellaneous water department fees. 
a.  Application for water service. 
b.  Temporary meter use. 
c.  Main inspection. 
d.  Fire protection system connection assembly inspection. 
e.  Install or move a temporary two-inch service or fire hydrant. 
f.  The service charge for readiness to serve private fire protection systems within or outside the city, not metered, is hereby established as a separate fee. Such charges shall be payable annually in advance to the city. No water is to be used from fire protection systems at any point on the line except in case of fire; nor are any fixtures other than those used for fire protection to be connected to such fire line. 
g.  The department may reinstall a service of the same size and turn-on at curb stop, if the service meets departmental standards. If it does not, the customer will be charged all costs necessary to restore the service to the departmental standards and payment the new service installation charge.
