Site plan review as provided in this paragraph and seller's agreement to notify each buyer of a condominium or cooperative unit of the county recertification of buildings that are in existence for over 40 years and every ten years thereafter is also required prior to issuance by the city of zoning compliance pursuant to F.S. § 718.616(4). The recertification notification shall include a copy of Code of Miami-Dade County, Florida subsection 8-11(f), which requires a property owner to provide the building official with an architect or professional engineer's report certifying that the building or structure is structurally and electrically safe or has been made structurally and electrically safe for the specified use for continued occupancy and which further requires city approval upon inspection and payment of a fee. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 98-30, § 2, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 10-11-2005; Ord. No. 2007-87, § 1, 10-9-2007; Ord. No. 2008-86, § 1, 10-28-2008; Ord. No. 2018-100, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Sec. 1-3. - Decisions and conduct of hearings. 
(a)  Decisions on comprehensive plan amendments, including future land use map amendments. At a public hearing before the planning and zoning board upon application for a change in land use classification or other comprehensive plan amendments, the planning and zoning board makes its recommendation to the city council. At a hearing designated for decisions on comprehensive plan amendments, the city council may approve a resolution for adoption of a comprehensive plan amendment. The resolution is an expression of intent to consider a request for future adoption. The resolution is transmitted to the Florida Department of Community Affairs for review. The resolution must be approved by a five-sevenths vote of the city council for transmittal to the Florida Department of Community Affairs. If the Florida Department of Community Affairs issues its objections, recommendations and comments (ORC) report without objections, then the plan amendment may be adopted by ordinance. Adoption of a plan amendment by the city council shall be by affirmative vote of not less than a majority of the city council as provided in F.S. § 163.3184(15)(a), as amended. The effective date of the plan amendment shall be the date a final order is issued by the department of community affairs or an administration commission finding the amendment to be in compliance with F.S. § 163.3184, whichever occurs earlier. No development orders, development permits or land uses dependent on the amendment may be issued or commenced before it has become effective. If the department of community affairs issues a notice of intent to find the plan not in compliance, proceedings may be conducted before the division of administrative hearings of the department of management services, upon petition for formal hearing by the city or an affected person, in accordance with F.S. § 163.3184(10), as amended. If a final order of noncompliance is issued by the administration commission, this amendment may nevertheless be made effective by adoption of a resolution affirming its effective status, subject to sanctions, pursuant to F.S. § 163.3184(10). 
(b)  Zoning decisions of the city council recommended by the planning and zoning board. At a public hearing, the planning and zoning board makes its recommendation on an application or petition. The planning and zoning board may recommend to deny an application or to approve an application. The planning and zoning board may recommend approval of an application with modifications only if the applicant amends his/her application or proffers an amended request to the board. The city council may override by a five-sevenths vote or adopt the recommendation of the planning and zoning board by ordinance. All applications for more than one variance shall be treated as a single request and accordingly, the planning and zoning board must vote only on the request as a whole, and not separately on the individual items that comprise the request. Bifurcation of a rezoning request from accompanied variance requests may be permitted at the discretion of the planning and zoning board. 
(c)  Final decisions of the planning and zoning board. At a public hearing, the planning and zoning board shall make its decision on an application on matters that require a final decision. The planning and zoning board shall make final decisions on petitions requesting setback and other adjustments that do not seek rezoning, a use variance, a special use permit or a conditional use permit, and on petitions requesting variances of sign regulations concerning the number, location, type and features of a sign. Also, the planning and zoning board shall make final decisions on appeal of decisions of the administrative variance committee. The decision shall be in writing and signed by the presiding member of the planning and zoning board. The date of the decision shall be the date of the public hearing wherein the decision was announced. 
(d)  Decisions of the administrative variance committee. The administrative variance committee may approve or approve with conditions applications or requests for administrative variances which permit variations up to but not exceeding 20 percent of the ordinance requirements for minimum yards and setbacks, minimum landscaping, maximum size and number of signs, location, type and features of signs, minimum and maximum floor area, maximum lot coverage, maximum height, length and width of buildings, minimum spacing requirements between principal and accessory buildings and sign regulations. 
(e)  Conduct of hearings. The planning and zoning board and city council may establish its own policies and procedures for the governance of its hearing, including but not limited to the conduct of hearings, presentation of evidence and examination of witnesses. Limitation of the number of speakers both for and against an application and the limitation of the amount of time allotted for each speaker shall be permitted in accordance with due process. 
(Ord. No. 96-2, § 2, 1-23-1996; Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Sec. 1-4. - Appellate remedies generally. 
(a)  Decisions of the city council. The zoning decisions of the city council are considered final administrative orders, which are appealable, by certiorari, to the circuit court in accordance with the Florida Rules of Appellate Procedure. Renewed requests on applications for change of zoning and zoning variances and use permits that require adoption of an ordinance may be prohibited for one year by procedure instituted by the planning and zoning board. There are no other time limitations imposed by the Hialeah Code or Charter which would prevent a renewed request on matters presentable to the planning and zoning board as final decision maker or to the city council via the planning and zoning board. 
(b)  Final decisions of the planning and zoning board. The final decisions of the planning and zoning board shall be reviewed by the city council. The city council is authorized to affirm, affirm with conditions or override the decisions by resolution. The city council will conduct a de novo review of the decisions. The property owner, objectors and interested parties may offer or submit additional evidence and testimony at the hearing before the city council. The review will be heard at the earliest regularly scheduled city council meeting after the decision of the planning and zoning board is signed; provided that the appeal of the decision is advertised in a newspaper according to state law at least ten days prior to hearing. 
(c)  Decisions of the administrative variance committee. A property owner requesting an administrative variance shall have a right to proceed de novo before the planning and zoning board if any of the following events occur: 
(1)  If the property owner objects to the committee's decision to approve the requests with conditions; 
(2)  If a property owner in the area, affected by the decision, objects to the decision of the committee in writing and the objection is received by the city within 14 calendar days of the date of publication of the decision of the committee; and 
(3)  If less than a majority of a quorum of the committee members vote affirmatively for the request to be approved or approved with conditions. 
(d)  Challenges of the consistency of a development order with the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan. Standing to enforce the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan through development orders is governed by the provisions to F.S. § 163.3215, as amended. However, an applicant may have a common law right to petition for certiorari review in circuit court. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2001-10, § 2, 2-13-2001) 
Sec. 1-5. - Comprehensive plan amendments. 
    The procedure for comprehensive plan amendment applications is governed by Hialeah Code sections 98-102 and 98-103, as amended from time to time. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2014-14, § 2, 3-11-2014) 
Sec. 1-6. - Evaluation and appraisal of comprehensive plan. 
(a)  Evaluation and appraisal reports (EAR). It is the intent of the local government comprehensive planning and land development regulation act that adopted comprehensive plans be periodically updated through evaluation and appraisal reports to reflect changes in state policy on planning and growth management. An evaluation and appraisal report shall comply with the requirements of F.S. § 163.3191, as amended, and F.A.C. 9J-5.0053. The City of Hialeah submitted its adopted evaluation and appraisal report to the South Florida Regional Planning Council for sufficiency review on January 20, 1998, which was found sufficient by the South Florida Regional Planning Council. The city authorized the delegation of its initial sufficiency review to the South Florida Regional Planning Council by resolution. Subsequent evaluation and appraisal reports shall be submitted on a five-year interval thereafter. Evaluation and appraisal reports shall be prepared in conformity with the public participation procedures set forth herein in accordance with the public participation requirements of F.S. § 163.3181 and F.A.C. 9J-5.004, as amended. 
(b)  Procedure for public participation. Public participation is guaranteed at advertised public hearings before the planning and zoning board and the city council. Notice of hearings shall be advertised in a newspaper of general circulation in the area and posted conspicuously inside city hall. The planning division will be available to answer inquiries about the process and shall make available agendas of meetings and summaries of official action taken at meetings. The planning division shall make available copies of the zoning code, land development code, Hialeah Comprehensive Plan for purchase at the office of the city clerk and/or planning division. The city shall keep its citizenry apprised of planning activities through public workshops, public service announcements and written information. At advertised public workshops, the public will be invited to submit written or oral comments. The consideration of and response to public comments will be reflected in the minutes of all public hearings and workshops. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 98-30, § 2, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Sec. 1-7. - Certificate of reoccupancy. 
    Prior to purchase, sale, conveyance and transfer of title to any single-family, duplex or townhouse dwelling, a certificate of reoccupancy must be obtained. The certificate of reoccupancy, if issued, shall state that the city has inspected the dwelling and determined that the dwelling complies with the residential occupancy regulations of the zoning district on the property wherein the dwelling unit is located. The procedures are provided in section 98-415 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2002-29, § 2, 5-14-2002) 
Sec. 1-8. - Tenant certificates. 
    The Elderly Homeowners Relief Act authorizes, upon issuance of a tenant certificate, the establishment of one rental occupancy within a detached single-family residence or garage or accessory building of a single-family home, where the owner or co-owner is at least 55 years old and the property owner currently resides and uses the property as homestead. The procedures are provided in section 98-416 of the Code. 
(Ord. No. 2012-45, § 1, 8-28-2012) 
Sec. 1-9. - Intergovernmental coordination element. 
(a)  Definition. The purpose of an intergovernmental coordination element is to provide the City of Hialeah, as a local government, an opportunity to coordinate with adjacent local governments on land use planning and growth management issues which may have extra jurisdictional impacts. The requirements of an intergovernmental coordination element are provided in F.S. § 163.3177(6)(h), as amended. The intergovernmental coordination element will show relationships and state principles and guidelines to be used in coordinating the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan with the plans of school boards and other units of local government providing services but not having regulatory authority over the use of land, with the comprehensive plans of adjacent municipalities, the county, adjacent counties, or the region, and with the state comprehensive plan, as the case may require. 
(b)  Time schedule. The city shall transmit its proposed intergovernmental coordination element to the department of community affairs by schedule provided by the department of community affairs. The city shall transmit its adopted intergovernmental coordination element to the department of community affairs on or before December 31, 1999. Within one year of adoption of the intergovernmental coordination element, each county, all the municipalities within that county, the district school board, and any unit of local government service providers in that county shall establish interlocal or other form agreements setting forth joint processes for collaborative planning and decision making on population projections and public school siting, the local and extension of public facilities subject to concurrency, and siting facilities with countywide significance, including unwanted land uses whose nature and identity are established in an agreement. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 98-30, § 2, 4-14-1998) 
Note- Formerly, § 1-8. 
Sec. 1-10. - Development agreements. 
(a)  Authority. The city may consider and enter into development agreements with any person having a legal and equitable interest in real property located within its jurisdiction in accordance with the Florida Local Government Development Agreement Act, as provided in F.S. §§ 163.3220-163.3243, as amended. 
(b)  Definition. A development agreement is an agreement entered into pursuant to the Florida Local Government Development Agreement Act between the city, as a local government, and a developer regarding development of a particular parcel of land. A development agreement shall not exceed 30 years in duration, unless extended by mutual consent of the city and the developer, subject to a public hearing in accordance with F.S. § 163.3225. No development agreement shall become effective or implemented by the city unless the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and plan amendments implementing or related to the agreement are in compliance with the provisions of F.S. § 163.3184, as amended. 
(c)  Requirements and procedures. The requirements and procedures are governed by the Florida Local Government Development Agreement Act, as provided in F.S. §§ 163.3220-163.3243. 
(Ord. No. 2018-100, § 1, 9-25-2018) 
Note- Formerly, § 1-9. 
Sec. 1-11. - Vesting rights and takings. 
(a)  Definitions. Vested rights may operate to prevent the city from revoking certain previously approved development orders if the landowner has relied upon the approval to his detriment. A taking of private property without just compensation ("taking") can occur when government action deprives the landowner of all use of his property, First English Evangelical Lutheran Church v. County of Los Angeles, 482 U.S. 304, 107 S.Ct. 2378 (1987) and Lucas v. South Carolina Coastal Council, 505 U.S. 1003, 112 S.Ct. 2886 (1992), or deprives the landowner of all beneficial use of the land. 
(b)  Procedure. No applicant claiming that a particular development order constitutes or would constitute a taking or an abrogation of vested right may pursue such a claim in court or before a quasi-judicial body unless he has first exhausted the administrative remedies provided herein. Claims of a taking or abrogation of vested rights are limited solely to extreme circumstances rising to the level of a potential denial of rights under the Constitutions of the United States and the State of Florida or as now provided in the Private Property Rights Protection Act. The procedures provided herein or demonstrating such a taking or abrogation of vested rights are not intended to be utilized routinely or frivolously, but only in the extreme circumstances described above. 
(1)  To initiate a claim, the applicant must file a "notice of invoking administrative remedies" with the planning division, on a form prescribed by the planning division, accompanied by an administrative fee in an amount of $250.00 or such other amount approved by the city council. The notice of invoking administrative remedies must be filed within 15 days of the denial of a development permit or not later than 45 days before the first hearing on a development order or action which requires the approval of the city council or city agency or department if the claimant is challenging some intended or future action. 
(2)  The applicant shall file a complete sworn statement within 90 days of the filing of the notice of invoking administrative remedy. The applicant shall submit a sworn statement setting forth the facts upon which the claim is based and shall attach copies of any contracts, letters, appraisals, reports or other documents upon which the claim is based. The sworn statement shall provide a list of the names and addresses of any witnesses that the applicant shall present in support of the claim and a summary of the testimony of each witness. The signature of the claimant or the attorney on the sworn statement shall constitute a certification that the person signing has read the document and to the best of his knowledge it is supported by good grounds and that it has not been presented solely for delay. The claimant and the attorney of the claimant shall have a continuing obligation throughout the proceedings to correct any statement or representation found to have been incorrect when made or which becomes incorrect by virtue of changed circumstances. If a claim of taking or abrogation of vested rights is: (1) based upon facts that the claimant or the attorney knew or should have known was not true; or (2) frivolous or filed solely for the purposes of delay, the city council shall make a finding and may pursue any remedy or impose any penalty provided by law or ordinance. 
(3)  The grounds for the notice and sworn statement must allege that the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan, as applied to a particular developmental order or action, constitutes or would constitute a temporary or permanent taking of private property or an abrogation of vested rights. For example, an applicant may allege that the denial of a permit based on inconsistency with the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan constituted a taking or abrogation of vested rights. The applicant must allege, as a prerequisite for standing, the following: (1) Reliance upon some action or omission of the city; and (2) detrimental reliance, i.e., the applicant invested funds or incurred binding obligations that would represent real injury if such development is denied. 
(4)  The planning division and the law department shall make separate recommendations on each claim or individual matter. The planning division shall review the claim to ensure that all required information and documentation has been provided. The planning division and the law department shall be guided by applicable principles of land use planning and law respectively. 
(5)  The matter will be scheduled for a public hearing before the growth management advisory committee where evidence will be heard and upon which the growth management advisory committee shall make a recommendation to the city council. The city council shall decide the matter presented. 
(Ord. No. 96-2, § 2, 1-23-1996; Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 98-30, § 2, 4-14-1998; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Note- Formerly, § 1-10. 
Sec. 1-12. - Nonconformities. 
(a)  Determination of nonconforming use. A lawful use of property that existed at the time of adoption of the final land development code is considered nonconforming if its continued use varies from the requirements of the land development code, as amended. A nonconforming use may continue on property subject to the provisions contained in this division. A nonconforming use shall not be based on causal, temporary or illegal uses of property. 
(b)  Limitations. 
(1)  A nonconforming use may not be enlarged, intensified, increased or extended to occupy a greater area in any direction nor shall such use be replaced by another use not specifically permitted in the zoning district concerned. Land that has a nonconforming use may neither be subdivided nor improved with a structure or building. 
(2)  Notwithstanding the limitations in subsection (b)(1) of this section, a variance may be granted for an enlarged, intensified, increased or an extended nonconforming use if it is determined that such use is more compatible with the surrounding properties and area than at the time when the use became nonconforming and if it does not adversely affect or impact the public interest. Compliance with the current requirements of the city fire prevention code and building codes is mandatory for such approved uses. 
(c)  Discontinuance. Nonconforming uses that are discontinued for more than 90 consecutive days or for 180 days within a one-year period shall terminate and no longer exist. 
(d)  Termination. Nonconforming uses may be terminated by a five-sevenths vote of the city council by ordinance if the continuation of the nonconforming use adversely affects the health, safety and welfare of the city; provided, however, due consideration is given to the rights of the property owner in providing a reasonable time for compliance with current regulations. 
(e)  Undeveloped or vacant subdivided land. 
(1)  Individual platted lots. Except as provided in subsection 98-348(a), if an individual lot has been legally subdivided pursuant to a plat recorded in the public records of Miami-Dade County, prior to the adoption of the land development code as amended, the individual lot, if lawful at the time of recording, becomes a nonconforming use if it varies from the requirements of the land development code, as amended; provided, however, that the lot owner does not own a lot abutting the individual lot. If the lot owner owns an abutting lot, the requirements of the land development code, as amended, must be satisfied. 
(2)  Two or more platted lots or parts thereof. Except as provided in subsection 98-348(a), a nonconforming use will not be allowed if two or more contiguous lots or portions of lots with continuous frontage are owned by the same person. The property owner must comply with the current requirements of the land development code, as amended. 
(f)  Developed property. 
(1)  Restoration or replacement permitted. If a building or structure contains a nonconforming use, removal or destruction of the building or structure terminates the nonconformity. Destruction shall mean damage to an extent that repair or renovation would amount to 50 percent or more, or 25 percent or more if damage is structural, of the value of the building or structure as determined by the building official according to the standards set forth in the South Florida Building Code, as amended. Where damage is less than 50 percent, or less than 25 percent if damage is structural, of the value determination, the building or structure may be restored or renovated to the same or lesser size in the same location; provided, however, that restoration commences within six months of date of damage and is diligently completed. 
(2)  Individual platted lots. For individual platted lots, the same regulations apply as provided for undeveloped or vacant subdivided land in subsection (e) of this section. 
(3)  Two or more platted lots or parts thereof. For two or more platted lots or parts thereof, the same regulations apply as provided for undeveloped or vacant subdivided land in subsection (e) of this section. 
(g)  Eminent domain. In circumstances where a property owner receives proceeds as a result of a final judgment in eminent domain proceedings initiated by a governmental entity or government agency or receives monetary funds as part of a settlement in lieu of, in anticipation of, or as a result of eminent domain proceedings to cure a nonconformity created by the taking or acquisition of property by the governmental entity or agency, the property owner must use the proceeds or funds to cure the nonconformity on the affected property within 18 months of receipt of such proceeds or funds. The property owner shall obtain a building permit within six months of receipt of proceeds or funds to commence construction in effecting the cure. The duty to cure shall extend to successors in interest if the property owner sells, assigns, transfers or otherwise disposes of the property prior to curing the property. 
(Code 1960, § 32-210; Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 99-71, § 3(32-210), 5-25-1999; Ord. No. 2006-67, § 1, 10-10-2006) 
Note- Formerly, § 1-11. 
Sec. 1-13. - Hialeah Heights. 
(a)  Covenant Community. All residential development shall be maintained, improved or changed according to the procedures and requirements set forth in a declaration of restrictive covenants covering the premises of a residential development district, acceptable to the city, that shall have same legal effect as residential development district regulations. The declaration of restrictive covenants shall constitute covenants running with the land and be recorded in county public records. The declaration of restrictive covenants shall be signed by the developer of the residential development district and architectural control committee prior to the sale of the first residential unit and shall be incorporated by reference in the deed of the property conveyed by the developer to the first buyer. 
(b)  Architectural control committee. The architectural control committee shall consist of a minimum of three members and a maximum of five members, who have been assigned the continuing rights and duties by the developer to oversee and undertake the application and enforcement of the declaration of restrictive covenants and to review and consider any and all proposed changes to the structure, appearance or specifications of any residential building or lot that do not modify the approved site plan and do not vary from the Hialeah Heights Master Plan for Residential Development. The number and appointment of members to the architectural control committee and the terms of service shall be provided in the declaration of restrictive covenants; provided that the majority of members are residential unit owners within the affected residential development after the developer sells a majority of the residential units within the residential development. In addition to enforcement powers of the architectural control committee, the city may also enforce the provisions of the declaration of restrictive covenants by citation, notice of violation, injunction or other legal or administrative remedies. 
(c)  Redevelopment of landfill sites. On properties under a closure plan approved by county department of environmental resources (DERM), on properties that have finalized such closure plan or on properties that will be required to enter into a closure plan with DERM prior to redevelopment, the city will allow the elevation and slope of the land that was formerly used as a landfill for which buildings and structures shall be constructed to be limited as follows: 
(1)  The elevation of land less than or equal to 20 acres shall not exceed 14 feet from the crown of the road that is either adjacent to, abutting, or in the closest proximity to, the land. The measurement includes the additional layer of clean fill that is required to be placed on top of property that was used as a landfill. If there is a corner lot or property where a property abuts two rights-of-way where the crown of the road of each right-of-way is measured at different heights, the crown of the abutting right-of-way that is higher shall apply for the entire property. 
(2)  The elevation of land that is greater than 20 acres developed as one site or as phased development titled under the same property owner or affiliated company shall conform to the following topography: 
Maximum percentage of total gross acreage Maximum

(3)  Slope. The slope of the property shall be no greater than the angle of 10 degrees. 
For land greater than 20 acres developed as one site or as phased development titled under the same property owner or affiliated company, the slope of the land may exceed an angle greater than ten degrees but no greater than 20 degrees only to allow adjustments for stormwater retention and landscape berms and swales; provided, however, that the slope of all vehicular rights-of-way and pedestrian pathways not exceed the angle of ten degrees at all locations. In addition, ancillary retaining walls may be constructed to accommodate the difference between maximum elevations if such walls include stairs or a ramp and otherwise are integrated into the surrounding buildings or structures. 
(4)  Properties fronting the western edge of NW 97 Avenue (West 36 Avenue). The first 1,320 feet adjacent to the property line shall have the lowest land elevation of the property. If the first 1,320 feet adjacent to the property line contains an upwards slope, the slope should be gradual and subtle; without creating hills and valleys, except to provide a landscape berm or enclosure of a production water well that may be located at or near the right-of-way. 
(5)  The land elevations on the property shall be designed to promote pedestrian access and the connectivity of the street network. 
(6)  Prior to the issuance of the building permit, the applicant shall obtain city approval of a land elevation plan than complies with the requirements of this section. 
(Ord. No. 2006-67, § 1, 10-10-2006; Ord. No. 2008-86, § 1, 10-28-2008)

REGULATION NO. 2 - USES OF LAND AND WATER[3] 

Footnotes: 
--- (3) --- 
Editor's note- The land development regulations are supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah. The land development regulation is not the sole source of information. The Code of Ordinances should also be consulted prior to taking development action. 

Sec. 2-1. - Purpose. 
    This section provides regulations for the use of land and water for land use categories included in the future land use element of the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan. This section provides an overview of the general requirements for the use of land and water within municipal boundaries and a correlation between land use classifications and zoning districts or areas. The regulations intend to permit the use and development of property in accordance with the goals, objectives and policies expressed in the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and to ensure the compatibility of adjacent land uses and the provision of open space. 
Sec. 2-2. - Relationship between land use classifications and zoning districts or designations. 
    The future land use element of the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan established land use classifications or categories of property within the City of Hialeah. Land use classifications of individual properties are identified in the future land use map included in the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan. Chapter 98 (zoning code) of the Hialeah Code identifies the zoning districts or designations within the City of Hialeah. The land use classifications provide perimeters [parameters] and guidelines for present and future land development. The zoning districts provide parameters for the extent of permitted uses for designated properties. If there is a conflict between the uses permitted within an existing zoning district and the use of land permitted within a land use classification with respect to a particular property, then the use permitted within the designated land use classification prevails. 
    Zoning districts or designations generally correspond to certain land use classifications or categories. The following table describes the relationship between zoning districts or designations and land use classifications or categories:

Sec. 2-3. - Requirements for the use of land and water. 
(a)  General requirements. 
(1)  Protect natural environmental assets, including potable water sources, water bodies, parks, open spaces, green areas, and trees. 
(2)  Protect clean air, natural light and ventilation. 
(3)  Enforce levels of service for water and sewers as adopted by the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and by the Hialeah Code. 
(4)  Enforce levels of service for solid waste collection as adopted by the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and by the Hialeah Code. 
(5)  Enforce levels of service for the primary road system as adopted by the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and by the Hialeah Code. 
(6)  Approve plats and land subdivisions in accordance with the requirements of state law, when applicable, the Miami-Dade County Code, when applicable, and the Hialeah Code, particularly Hialeah Code division 3 of article III of chapter 98, section 98-348, and division 10 of article V of chapter 98 relating to restrictions of the dimensions of lots. 
(7)  Ensure consistency of location and boundaries of properties identified on the future land use map and the zoning map. 
(8)  Provide regulation that will maintain and improve land values. 
(b)  Special use permit (SUP) requirements. 
(1)  Hialeah Code division 5 of article II of chapter 98 provides for a special use variance to allow an additional use of property that is not otherwise a permitted use. Accordingly, if the use is discontinued or no longer desired, the use variance may be repealed and rescinded by ordinance and the declaration of restrictive covenants canceled of record. 
(2)  A special use permit may be granted by the city council, upon a recommendation of the planning and zoning board, only if the applicant has provided the following upon request: 
a.  Proof of concurrency. 
b.  Execution of a legally sufficient declaration of restrictive covenants approved by the city. 
c.  Certification of adequate off-street parking. 
d.  Certification that the public health, safety and welfare will not be adversely affected by the special use requested. 
e.  Certification that safeguards will be provided for the protection of surrounding properties, persons and the maintenance of the value of the properties within the neighborhood. 
(c)  Conditional use permit (CUP) requirements. 
(1)  Section 98-181 provides for a conditional use permit (CUP) to all a use limited to a specific number of years and conditions of use for certain permitted uses within zoning districts that have extraordinary impacts on the surrounding neighborhood or area: cemeteries, community correctional centers or prisons, public garages, funeral homes, hospitals, houses of worship, hotels and motels, private schools, charter schools, vocational and technical schools, and post-secondary education facilities, colleges and universities. On property zoned R-1 (one-family district), a conditional use may be allowed for child day care facilities that are not state-licensed or state-registered family day care homes. If there is any departure, change or violation of the ordinance granting the CUP will be subject to revocation of an occupational license and repeal and rescission of the ordinance granting the CUP. 
(2)  A conditional use permit may be granted by the city council, upon review and recommendation of GMAC and the planning and zoning board, only if the application has provided the following upon request: 
a.  Proof of concurrency. 
b.  Execution of a legally sufficient declaration of restrictive covenants approved by the city. 
c.  Certification that the public health, safety and welfare will not be adversely affected by the special use requested. 
d.  Certification that the application, to the best of the applicant's knowledge and belief, satisfies the criteria set forth in Hialeah Code section 98-1115. 
(d)  Zoning designation of annexed properties. The city will assign zoning designations to annexed properties that correspond to existing city zoning designations. R-3-4 (multiple family) and R-3-5 (multiple family) are prohibited in the Hialeah Heights district. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 10-11-2005; Ord. No. 2008-86, § 1, 10-28-2008) 
REGULATION NO. 3 - WATER WELLFIELD PROTECTION[4] 

Footnotes: 
--- (4) --- 
Editor's note- The land development regulations are supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah. The land development regulation is not the sole source of information. The Code of Ordinances should also be consulted prior to taking development action. 
Cross reference- Water and sewers, ch. 94. 

Sec. 3-1. - Purpose 
    The purpose of this section is to provide regulation for protection of potable water wellfields in satisfaction of the requirements of F.S. § 163.3202 and F.A.C. 9J-24.004(c). This section supplements the Miami-Dade County Code § 24-12.1 et seq., also known as the Potable Water Supply Well Protection Ordinance, which is adopted by reference. The regulations provide control of land uses and activities within identified cones of influence for potable water wells and wellfields, in order to protect the potable water supply. 
    The Biscayne Aquifer is the source of the City of Hialeah's supply of potable water. To protect the quality of the Biscayne Aquifer, Miami-Dade County has instituted the wellfields protection program that restricts the types of uses permitted within wellfields located in urban areas. The parameters of the program are set forth in Miami-Dade County Code § 24-12.1 et seq. The provisions of the ordinance establish standards for land uses within cones of influence protecting public potable water supply wells from contamination in incorporated and unincorporated areas throughout Miami-Dade County. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Sec. 3-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  Cone of influence means an area around one or more major water wells the boundary of which is determined by the governmental agency having specific legislative authority to make such a determination based on groundwater travel or drawdown depth. 
(b)  Potable water means water that is suitable for drinking. 
Sec. 3-3. - Water shortage regulations. 
(a)  Definitions. In construing this section, where the context will permit and no definition is provided in this section, the definitions provided in F.S. ch. 373 and in the rules and regulations promulgated thereunder, as may be amended from time to time, shall apply. The following words, terms and phrases, when used in this article, shall have the meanings ascribed to them in this section, except where the context clearly indicates a different meaning: 
    District is the South Florida Water Management District. 
    Water resource means any and all water on or beneath the surface of the ground, including natural or artificial water courses, lakes, ponds or diffused surface water and water percolating, standing or flowing beneath the surface of the ground. 
    Water shortage condition means that situation when sufficient water is not available to meet present or anticipated needs of any person using the water resource or when conditions occur that require temporary reduction in total water usage within a particular area to protect the water resource from serious harm. A water shortage usually coincides with drought conditions. 
    Water shortage emergency means that situation when the powers that can be exercised under part II of chapter 40E-21, Florida Administrative Code, are insufficient to protect the public health, safety or welfare, or the health of animals, fish or aquatic life, or protect the public water resource from serious harm. 
(b)  Applicability. Water shortage regulations intend to protect the city water resources from the deleterious effects of overutilization during water shortages and assist the South Florida Water Management District in implementing its water shortage plan. These regulations apply to any person using the water resource within the geographic areas subject to a water shortage emergency or water shortage as determined by the district, whether from public or privately-owed water utility systems, private wells or private connections with surface water bodies. These regulations do not apply to a person using treated effluent or saltwater. 
(c)  Upon a declaration of a water shortage or water shortage emergency within all or any part of the city by the governing board or the executive director of the district, all water use restrictions or other measures adopted by the district applicable to the city shall be subject to enforcement action. The water shortage plan as promulgated in chapter 40E-21, F.A.C. shall then become effective. 
(Ord. No. 2002-29, § 2, 5-14-2002) 
Sec. 3-4. - Areas of concern. 
(a)  Aquifer recharge. The city shall control development that overlays recharge areas with impervious surfaces since impervious areas reduce percolation from rainfall and alter the level of the aquifer and its rate of recharge. 
(b)  Water contamination. The importance of maintaining the prime recharge capability of the surface area is underscored by the principles of gravity and the fact that significant groundwater contamination often occurs by pollutants carried by stormwater runoff. Accordingly, the city shall enforce to the extent permitted: 
(1)  Miami-Dade County regulations established for the protection of public potable water wells. 
(2)  Restrictions for the areas surrounding the Hialeah Wellfield also known as the John E. Preston Wellfield. 
(3)  Regulations enacted by the city for the protection of potable water. 
(4)  Chapter 94 of the Hialeah Code, as amended. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Sec. 3-5. - Regulations for the protection of potable water. 
(a)  Within the cone of influence identified in table 3-1, the planning division may only review uses that do not generate hazardous waste. Thus, the city may only approve uses permitted within the regulatory boundaries of cone of influence map (table 3-1); provided, however, that such uses are consistent with the Hialeah Comprehensive Plan and its future land use map. 
(b)  All permitted uses within the cone of influence located within municipal boundaries shall be connected to the sewer system of the City of Hialeah. 
(c)  Within the cone of influence, the city shall approve only developments that meet minimum requirements for percentage of pervious area. 
(d)  Uses within the area identified in table 3-1 as having a 210-day water travel time to a public well shall be restricted to uses that will not create water pollution. Uses such as gas stations, dry cleaning and photo processing shall be prohibited within the cone of influence unless permitted by Miami-Dade County when specific limitations are required. 
(e)  Deposit of hazardous waste in a landfill or illegal dump site, disposal of waste into storm or sanitary sewers, burial or injection of waste into water wells or other methods of waste disposal that threaten groundwater are prohibited. 
(f)  The measured impact or water requirements for any new development or redevelopment shall be provided in the concurrency proof. 
(g)  Before a development order is issued, the director of the water and sewers department shall sign the concurrency proof to ensure that water and sewer capacities are in compliance with pertinent regulation. 
(h)  For aquifer recharge, low density residential uses shall have a minimum of 30 percent of the lot area as pervious. Impervious surfaces shall have a minimum separation of two feet from the property lines; except impervious surfaces located on the front property line that are used for access, such as driveways or entrances, may be connected directly to the street and/or sidewalk. 
(i)  Prior to the issuance of a development order, the planning division shall review only developments designed to prevent direct discharge of stormwater into lakes or other bodies of water. 
(j)  For the protection of potable water wells, the city adopts the regulations of Miami-Dade County Code § 24-12.1 et seq., as amended. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999)

REGULATION NO. 4 - FLOOD CRITERIA[5]

Sec. 4-1. - Purpose. 
    The purpose of this section is to regulate areas subject to seasonal and periodic flooding in conformity with F.S. § 163.3202(2)(d) and F.A.C. 9J-24.003(d). 
Sec. 4-2. - Regulations. 
    This code adopts by reference article II of chapter 42 of the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah, Florida entitled "Flood Damage Prevention." The regulations provided in Hialeah Code article II of chapter 42 are incorporated herein by reference. 
REGULATION NO. 5 - COMPREHENSIVE STORMWATER MANAGEMENT[6] 

Footnotes: 
--- (6) --- 
Editor's note- The land development regulations are supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah. The land development regulation is not the sole source of information. The Code of Ordinances should also be consulted prior to taking development action. 
Cross reference- Floods, ch. 42. 

Sec. 5-1. - Purpose and establishment of stormwater utility. 
    The purpose of this section is to ensure that new land developments and redevelopments comply with federal, state and local stormwater management codes and standards. The City of Hialeah established a stormwater utility in 1998. The stormwater utility is a public body corporate and politic governed by the Hialeah City Council. The utility shall be responsible for the operation, maintenance and governance of a citywide stormwater utility plan, construct, operate and maintain stormwater management systems set forth in the local program required pursuant to F.S. § 403.0891. The director of the streets department shall be the director of the utility. The organization and operating procedures of the utility shall be prescribed by administrative orders and regulations of the mayor. Drainage facilities located on private property (on-site) are regulated by the City of Hialeah Planning and Development Department and the Miami-Dade County Department of Environmental Resources Management. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
Sec. 5-2. - Stormwater management regulations. 
(a)  All developed property, residential and nonresidential, shall pay a stormwater utility fee according to a fee schedule set by the Hialeah City Council. 
(b)  Management of stormwater quantity and quality within the municipal limits shall be implemented through a Hialeah Comprehensive Stormwater Master Plan. The stormwater master plan, developed in conjunction with the South Florida Water Management District, incorporates state water policy and district stormwater management goals in furtherance of F.S. ch. 403. 
(c)  The construction of all stormwater management facilities shall be in accordance with state regulations of stormwater discharge provided in F.A.C. 17-25.001 et seq. 
(d)  All stormwater management facilities constructed within municipal limits shall be approved by the water control section, Miami-Dade County Department of Environmental Resources Management (DERM) and by the appropriate development regulatory agency within city government. 
(e)  All stormwater management facilities shall be constructed in accordance with the standards and specifications contained in the current edition of the Public Works Manual, Part II, of Miami-Dade County, and Miami-Dade County Code, ch. 24, if applicable. 
(f)  Preexisting stormwater runoff characteristics of a site shall be preserved to the maximum extent that is practical during construction and afterwards. 
(g)  All development shall meet stormwater quantity level of service (LOS) requirements in accordance with the current Miami-Dade County/City of Hialeah Stormwater Master Plan. See table 5-1. 
(h)  All development shall meet stormwater quality level of service (LOS) requirements in accordance with the current Miami-Dade County/City of Hialeah Stormwater Master Plan. See table 5-2. 
(i)  Stormwater management design shall incorporate best management practices (BMPs) based on the "treatment train" concept depicted in figure 2-15. See table 5-3. 
(j)  Swales for stormwater runoff retention shall be used for both on-site and public right-of-way drainage to the maximum extent that is practical. 
(k)  On-site activities, during construction and afterwards, shall not violate any limitations restricting the City of Hialeah pursuant to the issuance of United States Environmental Protection Agency [NPDES (EPA)] Stormwater Discharge Permit No. FLS000023. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999)

REGULATION NO. 6 - ENVIRONMENTAL PROTECTION[7] 

Footnotes: 
--- (7) --- 
Editor's note- The land development regulations are supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah. The land development regulation is not the sole source of information. The Code of Ordinances should also be consulted prior to taking development action. 
Cross reference- Floods, ch. 42; parks and recreation, ch. 62; solid waste, ch. 78; streets, sidewalks and other public places, ch. 82; water and sewers, ch. 94; zoning, ch. 98. 

Sec. 6-1. - Purpose. 
    To provide for the conservation and environmentally sound use of the natural resources found within the city boundaries; and to enhance the quality of life, public health, safety and welfare of the community and its environment. 
Sec. 6-2. - General regulations. 
    The city shall enforce the following to conserve and protect the natural resources found within the city. 
(a)  Water bodies, surface and groundwater aquifer recharge areas: 
(1)  All new developments will be designed to prevent direct discharge of stormwater into lakes or other bodies of water. 
(2)  The first flush of rainfall will be retained on site to protect the underground water aquifer. 
(3)  Runoff from individual drainage systems should not adversely affect the groundwater aquifer water quality. 
(4)  Nutrient rich effluent shall not be discharged into surface waters. 
(5)  Sewers will be used to handle the sewage generated in the city. 
(6)  Land uses that generate hazardous wastes will not be permitted within the cone of influence except if permitted pursuant to special requirements of the Miami-Dade County Department of Environmental Resources Management (DERM). 
(7)  Developments within the cone of influence must comply with Potable Water Supply Well Protection Ordinance, Miami-Dade County Code § 24-12.1 et seq. 
(8)  Raw sewage will not be discharged into surface waters of the city. 
(9)  Developments will ensure that the recharge potential of the land is not lost by leaving the greatest amount of permeable area and properly retaining water runoff. 
(10)  All areas within buildings and loading areas where hazardous materials are to be used, handled, generated, or stored are to be constructed with impervious floors, without drains, to ensure containment, and facilitate clean up of any spill or leak. 
(11)  Encourage and promote public education on the proper use and handling of pesticides, used motor oils, paints, solvents, and other hazardous materials. 
(12)  New developments shall have stormwater management systems that are designed in accordance with the guidelines and criteria of affected regulatory agencies. 
(13)  Pollutant retardant structures that separate oils and grease from runoff will be incorporated into new drainage systems. 
(14)  To assist in the conservation of water, the use of xeriscaping, or other similar systems will be incorporated into new developments. 
(15)  New developments will utilize on-site lakes and wells as the major source of nonpotable water to reduce the demands on public potable water supplies. 
(16)  Water-saving devices will be installed in new structures and where feasible, retrofit existing buildings. 
(17)  Air quality. The city will work with the Miami-Dade County Department of Environmental Resources Management (DERM), the State of Florida Department of Environmental Planning [Protection] (DEP), and the U.S. Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) to attain national ambient air quality standards. 
(18)  Soil conservation. The development of land shall be accomplished in a manner that will not result in the loss of soil. The planning and development department will be the city department charged with enforcement. 
(Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999) 
REGULATION NO. 7 - SIGN REGULATION[8] 

Footnotes: 
--- (8) --- 
Editor's note- The land development regulations are supplements to the Code of Ordinances of the City of Hialeah. The land development regulation is not the sole source of information. The Code of Ordinances should also be consulted prior to taking development action. 
Cross reference- Sign regulations, § 74-146 et seq. 

Sec. 7-1. - Purpose. 
    This regulation provides an effective method of regulating existing and proposed signs and other street graphics within municipal boundaries. The purpose of sign regulation is to ensure that signs are compatible with their surroundings, protect property values, create a better business climate, enhance the physical appearance of the community, improve vehicular and pedestrian safety and reduce visual pollution. 
Sec. 7-2. - Definitions. 
(a)  Abandoned sign: Any sign located on property is considered abandoned if the advertised business, activity or other purpose is no longer licensed or is no longer doing business or operating at that location, or such other advertised location, for a period of 30 days or more. 
(b)  Animated sign: A sign or any part thereof that uses motion by any means or that displays flashing, oscillating, sequential or intermittent lights. 
(c)  Awning sign: A sign painted on an awning that is supported entirely from the exterior wall or building. 
(d)  Balloon sign: Any sign of fabric-type material inflated for the purpose of floating on or above the ground or a building. 
(e)  Banner sign means a sign having letters, characters or illustrations applied to cloth, plastics, paper or fabric of any kind with only such material for backing. This definition includes flag banners, sail banners, teardrop banners or feather banners. 
(f)  Billboard: Any sign advertising a commercial establishment, activity, person, product, facilities, service or entertainment that is sold, produced, manufactured, available or furnished at a place other than on the property upon which the sign is located. 
(g)  Box wall sign: A sign consisting of a box made of plastic, metal, wood or similar material which is mounted on a wall. 
(h)  Building frontage: The horizontal ground floor distance from one end of the building to the other, oriented to any street or drive, as determined by the director. If the end of the building is curved or angled, then the terminus will be established by interpolation. 
(i)  Bus bench sign: Any sign painted on or attached to a bench or shelter designed or intended for people awaiting public transportation. 
(j)  Canopy sign: A sign hanging underneath a pedestrian shelter canopy in a multitenant commercial center. 
(k)  Changeable copy sign: Sign copy or messages intended to be changed by removable letters and numerals. 
(l)  Channel letters: Letters affixed individually to a wall surface. 
(m)  Construction sign: A sign designating the name(s) of an owner, contractor, architect, engineer, or similar firm involved in demolition, renovation or construction at the site or location where the services are being rendered or work is performed. 
(n)  Copy area: See Sign area. 
(o)  Development identification sign: Any sign installed on a building or on the perimeter of a residential development identifying the name of the building or development. 
(p)  Director: The director of the City of Hialeah Planning and Development Department. 
(q)  Directory sign: An occupancy index of a residential, commercial or industrial building or multitenant center. 
(r)  Externally illuminated sign: A sign illuminated by shielded or indirect lighting which is not part of the sign. 
(s)  Facade: The building face from the ground to the roofline. 
(t)  Freestanding sign: A monument, pole or pylon sign. 
(u)  Garage or yard sale sign: Any point-of-sale sign that advertises a garage or yard sale on residential property consisting of the sale of used or old personal effects, clothing, furnishings, objects, furniture, books, appliances and similar items of the property owner or occupant that were not purchased or obtained for resale. 
(v)  Ground sign: See Monument sign. 
(w)  Internally illuminated sign: Any sign having characters, designs, logos or outlines illuminated by lights within the sign or luminous tubes designed for that purpose. 
(x)  LED sign means any sign made primarily of Light Emitting Diodes (LED). A full color LED sign means a sign that uses red, green and blue (RGB) colors comprising a "pixel" and which is similar to a computer monitor or television that displays colors to achieve high impact resolution or video. A single color or grayscale LED sign means any sign where the pixels comprise a single color, usually red or amber. Grayscale describes the ability of individual LEDs to vary in brightness to create shaded pictures or graphics. A nit is a unit of measure that measures the light emitted from an LED device. 
(y)  Instructional sign: 
(1)  A noncommercial sign permanently erected and/or maintained by any governmental agency. 
(2)  A noncommercial sign relating to an activity on premises upon which the sign is located, providing information to pedestrian and vehicular traffic, e.g., "entrance," "caution" and "no trespassing." 
(3)  A sign within, or at the entrance to, a development showing the name and directions to the location of the subdivisions comprising the development, the sales office, etc. 
(4)  A model sign defined as a sign designating a particular unit exhibited to depict similar units that are for sale or rent. 
(z)  Monument sign: A freestanding structure containing a sign face, supported solely by its own ground-mounted base (or two pole-like supports not to exceed 18 inches height) that is not attached or affixed in any way to another structure. 
(aa)  Multitenant center: A shopping, office or business complex in which two or more occupancies abut each other or share common parking facilities or driveways or are otherwise related. 
(bb)  Mural: An artistic picture on a wall whether painted, comprised of tile or other material which is not used primarily for purposes of identification, advertisement, display or information. 
(cc)  Nonconforming sign: An existing sign installed with a building permit which does not conform to the requirements of this chapter [regulation]. 
(dd)  Painted sign: A sign painted on an external surface. 
(ee)  Point-of-sale sign: Any sign advertising a commercial establishment, activity, person, product, facilities, service or entertainment that is sold, produced, manufactured, available or furnished on the property upon which the sign is located. 
(ff)  Pole sign: Any sign erected upon a single pole, which is wholly independent of any other structure for support. 
(gg)  Political campaign sign: Any sign that indicates the name, cause or affiliation of anyone seeking public office or that describes an issue for which a public election is scheduled to be held. 
(hh)  Portable sign: Any sign designed to be transported or any sign not permanently attached to the ground or to a permanent structure. Portable signs include, but are not limited to, signs capable of transport by wheels, skid-mounted signs, A-frame signs, T-frame signs, sandwich board signs and signs attached to or painted on vehicles parked for the purpose of advertising on or near to the public right-of-way. 
(ii)  Projecting sign: A sign directly attached to and extending from a building or other structure. 
(jj)  Pylon: A solid or double pedestal structure, either freestanding or as a vertical extension of a building extending from ground level to a point no higher than the roof line, used as support for a sign. A pylon constructed as a vertical extension of a building shall have the appearance of a solid structure. 
(kk)  Pylon sign: A flat sign attached to, or painted on, the face of a pylon. The outer edge of the sign shall neither extend beyond the pylon nor above the roof line. 
(ll)  Real estate sign: A temporary sign erected on site by the owner or his agent, indicating property which is for rent, lease or sale, open for inspection, shown by appointment or similar announcement. 
(mm)  Roof sign: A sign erected over, across or on the roof of any building that is dependent on the roof, parapet or upper walls of a building for support. A sign that is supported by the upper walls of a building is considered a roof sign only if the sign projects above the parapet or roof line. 
(nn)  Sign: Any structure and all parts composing the same, together with the frame, background or support therefor, that is used for identification, advertising, informational or display purposes or any statuary, sculpture, molding, casting or other objects used for identification, advertising, informational or display purposes. Merchandise, vehicles or equipment used to attract attention or to advertise, with or without a printed message, shall be considered a sign. 
(oo)  Sign area: The square foot area enclosed by the perimeter of the sign structure. When a sign is composed of individual letters, symbols or logos only, the sign area is the area enclosed by a perimeter line (forming a single rectangle or square or the aggregate of a series of rectangles and/or squares, if such calculation achieves a smaller sign area) enclosing all letters, symbols and logos. The sign area of a monument sign shall be measured by multiplying the height times the width. 
(pp)  Sign height: The height of the sign measured from the finished ground elevation to the top of the sign. If the area around the sign is bermed, then the height of the sign is determined from the crown of the fronting street. 
(qq)  Snipe sign: A sign nailed, glued or otherwise attached to trees, poles, walls, trash receptacles, fences or other objects. Legal notices required by law are exempted. 
(rr)  Swinging sign: Any sign that swings freely from or on supports regardless of guy wires used in connection therewith. 
(ss)  Temporary sign: Any sign to be displayed for a limited period as specified elsewhere herein. 
(tt)  Time and temperature sign: A display containing flashing, digital or illuminated numerals showing the time and/or temperature. 
(uu)  Wall sign: A sign which is affixed to or painted on and lying flat against an exterior wall, fascia, cantilever or marquee of any building that is parallel thereto and supported by such wall, fascia, cantilever, marquee or building. No wall sign shall project higher than the top of the wall, fascia or building and no sign shall be attached to a decorative architectural feature. 
(vv)  Window sign: Any sign attached to a store front window or door. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2002-29, § 2, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2010-67, § 1, 11-9-2010; Ord. No. 2013-54, § 1, 9-10-2013) 
Sec. 7-3. - Prohibited signs and sign devices. 
(a)  Abandoned signs. 
(b)  Billboards/ off-site signs. 
(c)  Fluttering, spinning or other similar devices except banner signs as provided in section 74-218(6). 
(d)  Flagpoles exceeding 30 feet in height; two poles shall be permitted for each building. For buildings that exceed 25,000 square feet in floor area, a maximum of four poles may be permitted. 
(e)  Pole signs. 
(f)  Portable signs, except such signs attached to or painted on vehicles, not higher than ten feet, including the frame and/or supporting base, from the road surface and not obstructing the view of other vehicular traffic as to create a danger to traffic and pedestrian safety, that are in transit on the roadways within the city. No portable sign may remain stationary for a period of longer than ten minutes. Storage of permitted portable signs shall be within enclosed walls wherein such signs shall not be visible to the public. 
(g)  Roof signs. 
(h)  Snipe signs, except legal notices required by law. 
(i)  Swinging signs. 
(j)  Signs on public property unless placed by governmental agencies located on public property for operational or informational purposes. 
(k)  Signs on utility poles except for utility identification. 
(l)  Signs that could be confused with traffic signals or traffic signs. 
(m)  Signs that in the opinion of the director constitute a safety hazard. 
(n)  Any projecting sign extending over a public right-of-way, except that a marquee sign, no less than nine feet in height, and an awning sign, no less than eight feet in height may be permitted to extend over the pedestrian portion of the right-of-way, no closer than 30 inches to the edge of the curb of the sidewalk. 
(Ord. No. 96-2, § 2, 1-23-1996; Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 2005-98, § 1, 10-11-2005; Ord. No. 2013-54, § 1, 9-10-2013) 
Sec. 7-4. - Required signs. 
(a)  Safety signs. Safety markings prescribed by fire authorities. 
(b)  House or building numbers. 
(1)  Residential building(s) with two dwelling units or less shall maintain on the wall of each such dwelling unit the designated address with numbers at least six inches in height but not greater than ten inches in height. The numbers comprising the street address shall be easily visible from the street or drive facing the front of the dwelling unit. 
(2)  Residential building(s) with more than two dwelling units and nonresidential buildings shall maintain on the wall of each such building the designated address with numbers at least ten inches in height, if the building faces a street or drive. The numbers comprising the street address shall be easily visible from the street or drive facing the front of the building. 
(3)  Residential units in buildings with more than two dwelling units and nonresidential units in multitenant centers shall maintain a letter or unit number identification with letters or numbers at least six inches in height displayed in a manner easily visible for police, fire and fire rescue accessibility and protection. 
(4)  Disabled parking and access signs must conform to the requirements of the Florida Americans with Disabilities Accessibility Implementation Act, as amended, and the Americans with Disabilities Act Accessibility Guidelines, as amended, and as incorporated and adopted by state law, or the requirements of Miami-Dade County, whichever is more restrictive. 
(5)  All assisted living facilities with 15 or more residents must identify the facility with lettering "ALF" at least six inches, but no more than ten inches in height adjacent to the address identification. All community residential homes housing 14 or fewer residents must identify the facility with lettering "CRH" at least six inches, but not more than ten inches, in height adjacent to the address identification. All residential care and treatment facilities must identify the facility with lettering "RCTF" at least six inches, but not more than ten inches, in height adjacent to the address identification. These identification signs must be easily visible from the street or property line facing the front of the building. If the residential buildings are located in residential areas or zoning districts, the type of sign is limited to an affixed wall or facade sign with the required lettering for identification and no other information that would constitute advertising or promotion. 
(6)  All family day care homes licensed or registered with the State Department of Children and Family services located in residential zoning districts must identify the facility with an affixed wall or facade sign with lettering "FDCH" at least six inches, but not more than ten inches in height, adjacent to the address identification if possible. All large child care homes licensed or registered with the state department of children and family services located in residential zoning districts must identify the facility with an affixed wall or facade sign with lettering "FCCH" at least six inches, but not more than ten inches in height, adjacent to the address identification if possible. These identification signs must be easily visible from the street or property line facing the front of the building. No other information or signage that would constitute advertising or promotion, including, but not limited to, murals, flags, banners and decorations, shall be allowed. 
(7)  Carbon monoxide lethal warning signs. At least two carbon monoxide lethal warnings signs shall be affixed to the interior walls of the garage, at a height easily visible and readable for a driver or passenger entering or exiting a motor vehicle providing language that explicitly warns people of the lethal danger of carbon monoxide exposure or inhalation from exhaust fumes from engines running in motor vehicles and from generators and other fossil fuel burning devices operating in enclosed garages. These warning signs shall be required on properties where motels, hotels, apartment hotels, condominiums and rooming houses with enclosed garages are located and where such garages are directly connected to residential units or bedrooms or indirectly connected to residential units or bedrooms through hallways, corridors or internal stairways. Each sign shall be at least 24 inches in height and at least 24 inches in width and shall provide in bold lettering in capitals at the top of the sign the words "CARBON MONOXIDE WARNING". All signs shall be approved by the city fire marshal pursuant to a sign permit that requires an application and inspection fee of $50.00 for signage within each enclosed garage and $150.00 for signage for two or more garages within each free-standing or separate motel building, apartment building, condominium building or rooming house on the property. The application and inspection fee is waived for not-for-profit corporations that are organized and operate for the purpose of educating the public on the dangers of carbon monoxide exposure. 
(c)  Wireless communication towers and antennas: 
(1)  Warning signs for high voltage. If high voltage is necessary for the operation of the communication tower or any accessory structures, "HIGH VOLTAGE-DANGER" warning signs shall be permanently attached to the fence or wall and spaced no more than 40 feet apart. 
(2)  Warning signs for trespassing. "NO TRESPASSING" warning signs shall be permanently attached to the fence or wall and spaced no more than 40 feet apart. 
(3)  General requirements for warning signs. The height of the lettering of the warning signs shall be at least 12 inches in height. The warning signs shall be installed at least five feet above the finished grade. The warning signs may be attached to freestanding poles if the content of the signs may be obstructed by landscaping. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 99-52, § 2, 4-27-1999; Ord. No. 2010-67, § 1, 11-9-2010; Ord. No. 2011-73, § 1, 10-11-2011) 
Sec. 7-5. - Legal nonconforming signs. 
(a)  1994 sign code legal nonconforming signs. Any point-of-sale sign that lawfully existed on January 10, 1995 may be continued, although it does not conform to all the provisions hereof, provided that no structural alterations are made hereto. 
(b)  Change of sign face, or change of configuration or shape of sign box. Any sign that lawfully existed on January 10, 1995 may be continued, although it does not conform to all the sections of this chapter, even if there is a change in sign face or change in configuration or shape of the sign box, provided that such change does not exceed the total square footage of the existing sign face or sign box. 
(c)  Pylon or pole signs. Any pylon or pole sign erected prior to January 30, 1987, will be continued, even if constructed without a building permit, provided that a cover, skirt or other architectural enhancement covers the pole base with a minimum width dimension of not less than 24 inches and provided that the sign conforms to foundation and electrical requirements of the South Florida Building Code. Proof of the sign's existence prior to January 30, 1987 will be presumed by identification of the sign in the 1987 aerial photographs produced by the county or from aerial photographs from earlier years. 
(d)  Termination of legal nonconforming signs. 
(1)  By abandonment. Abandonment of a legal nonconforming sign shall terminate its nonconforming status. 
(2)  By damage or poor condition. The legal nonconforming status of a sign shall cease whenever the sign is damaged beyond 50 percent of its replacement value as determined by the director, from any cause whatsoever, or to the extent the sign becomes a hazard or danger. 
(3)  Abandoned and damaged signs, as described herein, shall be removed in accordance with regulation 7-17 hereof. 
(e)  Biennial recertification of legal nonconforming billboards. On or before October 1, 2007 and every two years thereafter, the city shall recertify a legal nonconforming billboard located within the geographic limits of the city upon application of the sign owner or authorized representative together with payment of an initial certification fee in the amount of $3,000.00 and upon a determination that the billboard is in compliance with city code provisions, Florida building code and technical codes adopted by the city, after final inspection and approval by the building official. The sign owner shall obtain written permission from the property owner for city inspectors to enter private property to inspect the billboard at the time the application for recertification is submitted. The amount of the biennial recertification fee shall be reduced to $1,500.00 after payment of the initial certification fee and inspection of the legal nonconforming billboard. 
If a sign is not in compliance with the applicable codes, the city will provide a cure plan to correct the violations within a reasonable period of time. If the sign remains in noncompliance after the expiration of the curative time period, then the city shall revoke the annual sign permit in addition to other remedies provided in the Code or by law. If a sign owner does not recertify the billboard as provided herein, the city may suspend or revoke all occupational licenses issued to the property address of the property owner in addition to other remedies provided in the Code or by law. 
(Ord. No. 97-17, § 2, 3-25-1997; Ord. No. 2002-29, § 2, 5-14-2002; Ord. No. 2008-86, § 1, 10-28-2008; Ord. No. 2009-67, § 1, 9-8-2009) 
Sec. 7-6. - Signs not requiring a permit. 
(a)  Required signs specified in regulation 7-4. 
(b)  Traffic or provisional warning signs or structures providing street or traffic information or directions when required, or erected, by a governmental agency. 
(c)  Temporary signs specified in regulation 7-7. 
(d)  Signs used to assist traffic flow or parking on private property not exceeding four square feet in area per sign. 
(e)  Signs within a lobby or courtyard not visible from a public right-of-way, provided that the signs meet the structural requirements for signs as specified in the South Florida Building Code, as amended. 
(f)  Holiday decorations that do not require structural support or electrical connections unless a licensed electrician is required to obtain a permit to undertake the work. 
(g)  "No trespassing" and "no dumping" signs on private property, not to exceed four square feet in area per sign and not to be closer than 100 feet to another such sign, except that permission may be obtained from the director for additional signs under proven special circumstances. 
Sec. 7-7. - Specific purpose signs. 
(a)  Types of signs. Real estate, construction, and political campaign signs are considered specific purpose signs. 
(b)  Duration and removal. 
(1)  Specific purpose signs exceeding area and height limitations. All such signs conforming to the area and height limitations must be removed or replaced within 90 days of the date of installation, except as provided in this chapter. 
(2)  Specific purpose signs exceeding area and height limitations. Any person who intends to install a sign exceeding the area and height limitations set forth in this chapter, but in no event by more than 100 percent of such limitations, must apply for and obtain a sign permit prior to installation. All sign permit applications must be accompanied by a fee of $10.00. Such applications shall not include the submission and review of site plans. A sign requiring a permit pursuant to this subsection shall be permitted for a time period not to exceed 45 days from the date the sign is situated on the property. Removal is required if the sign has not been removed or replaced after 90 days, except as provided in this chapter. 
(3)  Bond required. If a person installs or causes to install in excess of 50 specific purpose signs, such person shall post a bond in the principal sum of $150.00 or the monetary amount of $150.00 as security for the recovery of expenses in connection with the city removing noncompliant signs. The bond or acceptance of monetary funds as security agreement shall contain language that authorizes the city to use all or any part of the principal of the bond or money retained to cover its expenses in removing the signs after notice to remove the signs has been provided and the signs have not been removed prior to time period provided in the notice or as provided in this chapter. The forfeiture of the bond or the withdrawal of the monetary funds retained as security does not prevent the city from collecting additional funds through citation or notice of violation to recover costs or penalties in connection with the maintenance and removal of unlawful temporary signs. 
(c)  Restrictions. Restrictions on specific purpose signs shall be as follows:

(d)  Setbacks; corner visibility. All signs, higher than three feet in height, shall not be located within a 25-foot triangle at the intersection of two streets measured along the property line. 
(e)  Building code compliance. A building permit is required to the extent a sign is constructed with a structure which requires a building permit under the South Florida Building Code.
